iii

LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 

Kingdom of Bhutan 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communication 
Subsector: Roads and highways 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth 
Subthemes: Fostering physical infrastructure development 
 
Category A 
The  summary  environmental  impact  assessment,  which  was 
submitted  to  the  Board  and  disclosed  to  the  public  through  the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  website  on  25  May  2005, 
includes  an  environmental  impact  assessment  for  the  national 
highway component and initial environmental examination for the 
feeder road component. 
 
The  Project  is  to  (i)  strengthen  part  of  the  Trongsa–Gelephu 
national highway (about 140 kilometers [km] of the total 245 km), 
including  a  16  km  realignment  between  the  Mangdichu  and 
Wangdigang  bridges;  and  (ii)  construct  4  feeder  roads:  Mirchim–
Bongo (17.5 km) and Tekizam–Bjena (6.5 km) in the west region, 
and  Garbagtang–Autsho  (51  km)  and  Khardungla–Kangpara  (28 
km)  in  the  east.  The  national  highway  component  includes  the 
replacement of two temporary bridges with permanent structures. 
Technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  the  Government  build  the 
capacity for road safety audit and road asset management. 
 
Accessibility  is  Bhutan’s  key  development  issue.  The  country’s 
trunk road network is still limited in terms of coverage and unable 
to  meet  the  growing  demands  of  larger  and  heavier  vehicles. 
Limited  provision  of  feeder  roads  adds  to  the  isolation  of  remote 
rural  areas.  To  cope  with  socioeconomic  development  and  the 
consequent  expansion  of  vehicular  traffic,  the  existing  road 
infrastructure must be upgraded and improved. 
 
Improving  part  of  the  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway  will 
result  in  a  39  km  reduction  in  highway  length  and  will  provide 
another subregional link with India in the long term, particularly for 
the  central  and  eastern  parts  of  the  country,  in  addition  to  the 
existing  link  via  the  Thimphu–Phuentsholing  road.  Expansion  of 
feeder roads is one of the Government’s priority strategies and is 
being implemented through external assistance. The feeder roads 
under the Project are included in the updated 9th Five-Year Plan 
and  selected  in  accordance  with  the  Government’s  policy  to 
realize regional balance and rural access. While ADB continues to 
support  development  agencies  focus  on  the  east  region,  with  its 
higher  poverty  incidence,  assistance  will  also  be  extended  to 
feeder roads in the west to improve rural access.

This is the first ADB project in Bhutan to finance improvement of a 
national  highway  and  construction  of  feeder  roads.  This  reflects 
the  Government’s  commitment  to  finance  resurfacing  as  well  as 
routine  maintenance  using  domestic  revenue  after  completion  of 
the ongoing ADB-funded Road Improvement Project. 
 
To  support 
for  private  sector 
participation in the construction industry, local competitive bidding 
will be used for all the construction works. 
 
The  Project  will  improve  transport  efficiency  on  the  trunk  road 
network  and  expand  accessibility  in  rural  areas,  which  will 
contribute  both  to  expansion  of  economic  opportunities  and 
poverty reduction.

The  existing  Project  Management  Office  (PMO),  which 
is 
responsible  for  implementing  the  Road  Improvement  Project,  will

office  will  be  based  in  Thimpu.  Once  phase  I  civil  works  are

Procurement of goods and services for the Project will be carried 
out  in  accordance  with  ADB  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  All  civil 
works  contracts  will  be  procured  under  local  competitive  bidding 
procedures.  Bidders  will  be  postqualified  by  applying  a  single 
stage,  two-envelope  bidding  procedure.  Advance  procurement 
action has been approved to accelerate project implementation. 
 
Design and supervision consultants will be recruited separately. A 
domestic  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  to  prepare  detailed 
design,  bidding  documents  for  pavement  strengthening  of  the 
national  highway;  and  to  assist  DOR  with  procurement  and 
preparation  of  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  for 
feeder  roads.  An  international  consulting  firm  in  association  with 
domestic consultants will be recruited for construction supervision. 
DOR  staff  will  be  released  for  site  inspection  tasks  to  assist  the 
supervision consultant. 
 
An  individual  domestic  consultant  will  be  engaged  to  assist  DOR 
in  monitoring  implementation  of  land  acquisition.  A  second 
individual  domestic  consultant  will  be  engaged  to  assist  DOR  in 
handling environmental concerns related to DOR activities. 
 
All  consultants  financed  from  the  ADB  loan  will  be  selected  and 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  for  recruitment  of  domestic 
consultants acceptable to ADB. 
 
The  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway  is  a  strategic  road  link, 
connecting the Indian border at Gelephu and the main east-west 
highway  at  Trongsa.  It  is  a  primary  conduit  for  long-distance 
traffic.  The  feeder  roads  will  provide  access  to  rural  areas 
presently not connected by motorable road. The areas benefiting 
are widely distributed in various dzongkhags (administrative units 
in

consequently  support  the  economic  and  social  development  of 
large parts of the country.

increased  service  frequency  and  lower  fares;  (iii)  increasing

 The  Project  will  improve  the  attractiveness  of  areas  in  the 
hinterlands for business and private sector investments, especially 
around  Gelephu  and  for  agroindustries.  Tourism  opportunities 
may also increase. Lack of and costly transport presently hinders 
the  development  of  industries  where  transport  costs  are  a  major 
component  of  the  final  price  and  the  final  product  perishable.  In 
general,  local  businesses  will  (i)  gain  access  to  lower  priced 
inputs,  (ii)  export  products  more  cheaply,  and  (iii)  improve 
productivity.  Agriculture,  tourism,  cottage  and  small  industries, 
and supporting services will all benefit. 
 

 
Risks and Assumptions  Major  risks  to  the  Project  relate  to  timely  project  implementation, 
which  will  be  mitigated  by  advance  actions  for  consultant 
recruitment and procurement, detailed planning of preconstruction 
and construction activities, and advance preconstruction activities 
such  as  survey  and  design  for  the  realignment  and  feeder  roads 
by  DOR.  The  survey  and  design  will  be  assisted  by  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency (JICA) experts working in DOR. 
Local contractors will be given sufficient time to prepare a detailed 
construction plan and obtain various government clearances, such 
as  for  quarry  sites,  before  commencing  works.  Potential  risks 
relating  to  environmental  impacts  are  mitigated  through  the 
detailed  mitigation  measures  set  out  in  summary  environmental 
impact  assessment,  which  will  be  monitored  by  a  consultant. 
Social  and  land  acquisition  issues  will  be  minimal  as  the 
resettlement  plan  will  be  prepared  before  contract  awards  in  line 
with the resettlement framework. Social and resettlement activities 
will be monitored by consultants engaged under the Project. 
 
In  conjunction  with  the  Project,  a  TA  will  (i)  strengthen  DOR’s 
capacity  in  road  asset  management,  and  (ii)  develop  DOR 
capacity in road safety audit. The estimated total cost of the TA is 
$376,000,  of  which  ADB  will  finance  $300,000  on  a  grant  basis 
from  the  Japan  Special  Fund,  funded  by  the  Government  of

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Kingdom  of  Bhutan  for  the  Road  Network  Project.1  The  report  also  describes  proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Capacity  Building  in  Road  Asset  Management  and  Road  Safety 
Audit, and if the Board  approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority  delegated to 
me by the Board, will approve the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

In a landlocked country like Bhutan, socioeconomic development depends largely on an 
2. 
efficient  and  reliable  road  network.  Since  the  construction  of  the  179  kilometer  (km) 
Phuentsholing–Thimphu Highway in 1959, the country has expanded the national road network. 
It has now about 4,153 km of motorable roads, including 1,577 km of national highways, 459 km 
of district roads, 1,205 km of feeder roads, 117 km of urban roads, 251 km of farm roads and 
543  km  of  forest  roads.  This  gives  a  road  density  of  0.1  km/square  km  (km2)  and  5  km/1,000 
inhabitants. The latter is relatively high in comparison with countries of similar size and income 
level,  due  to  Bhutan’s  low  population  density.  Despite  the  present  road  network,  many  rural 
communities still remain unconnected. Half the country’s population lives more than half a day’s 
walk from the nearest motorable road. Other than the traditional surface border crossings with 
the People’s Republic of China and India, only one airport provides limited air access to the rest 
of the world. Appendix 2 presents an analysis of the road sector; a summary follows. 
 
3. 
All  national  highways  and  nearly  half  of  the  district  and  feeder  roads  are  paved; 
however, 20% of national highways, 53% of district roads, and 86% of feeder roads are in poor 
condition.  Roads  with  narrow  carriageway  widths  were  built  along  steep  hillsides  prone  to 
landslides.  Roads  become  difficult  to  use  during  the  winter  months  and  rainy  season. 
Improvement, maintenance, and expansion of the existing road network are urgent. Because of 
the mountainous terrain, the area of land suitable for agriculture is limited and the population of 
less  than  700,000  is  distributed  in  remote  scattered  settlements.  This  situation  makes 
construction and maintenance of roads extremely difficult and costly. In addition, the wide use of 
manual resurfacing can only provide a low quality of pavement. 
 
4. 
Until  the  early  1990s,  most  of  the  country's  main  road  network  was  constructed  and 
maintained by DANTAK (an organization under the Army Engineering Corp of the Indian Border 
Force)  and  grant  financed  by  the  Government  of  India.  About  15%  of  Bhutan’s  main  road 
network  (574  km,  of  which  498  km  are  national  highways,  62  km  district  roads,  and  16  km 
feeder roads) is still maintained by DANTAK and funded by the Government of India, in addition 
to selected new construction and upgrading works. The Department of Roads (DOR) under the 
Ministry  of  Works  and  Human  Settlement  (MOWHS)  has  direct  responsibility  for  2,120  km, 
including 1,062 km of national highways, 415 km of district roads, 554 km of feeder roads, and 
89 km of urban roads. 
 
5. 
The  Government  is  redefining  its  role  from  that  of  executing  project  implementation  to 
service purchaser of transport infrastructure and services. MOWHS is responsible for the overall 
policy  making  and  planning  of  road  development  and  maintenance  through  the  Policy  and 

                                                 
1  The  Project  was  prepared  through  ADB.  2003.  Technical  Assistance  to  Bhutan  for  Preparing  the  Road  Network 

Expansion Project. Manila (TA 4138, approved on 2 July 2003). 

 2 

 

 

 

Planning  Division  based  on  requirements  proposed  by  DOR.  DOR,  still  heavily  involved  in 
survey and design works through the Survey and Design Division, intends to reduce the number 
of  staff  by  making  some  operations  more  efficient,  e.g.,  proposed  corporatization  of  the 
mechanical  division,  and  natural  reduction  of  the  National  Work  Force,  which  is  in  charge  of 
daily  routine  maintenance  works.  An  increased  amount  of  road  construction  and  maintenance 
work has been contracted to private contractors, in line with improvements to their financial and 
technical  capacity.  DOR  will  set  up  an  investigation  and  development  division  to  enhance  its 
capacity  for  road  asset  management  and  technology.  Under  MOWHS,  the  Standards  and 
Quality Control Authority is responsible for standards and quality assurance of all construction 
works.  The  Construction  Development  Board  is  responsible  for  registration  of  contractors  and 
consultants, and facilitation of private sector development and participation. Road safety is the 
responsibility  of  the  Road  Safety  and  Transport  Authority  (RSTA)  under  the  Ministry  of 
Information and Communications; except for engineering/design aspects, which are coordinated 
with DOR. RSTA is also responsible for regulation of the transport industry. 
 
6. 
The vehicle fleet has grown rapidly in recent years. From a total of 13,600 vehicles at the 
end of 1997, it reached 26,700 at the end of 2004, giving a growth rate of over 15% per annum. 
Light  vehicles,  and  in  particular  taxis,  increased  faster  than  the  average,  while  two-wheelers 
increased  at  a  slower  pace.  Almost  90%  of  the  vehicles  are  in  the  western  areas  of  Thimphu 
and Phuentsholing. Over two thirds of light vehicles are in the capital area, while 70% of trucks 
are  registered  at  Phuentsholing.  To  streamline  the  transport  system,  all  motor-vehicle-related 
activities,  including  registration  and  licensing,  and  roadworthiness  and  emission  tests  were 
consolidated under RSTA at the beginning of 1997. 
 
Traffic  volumes  are  highest  in  the  vicinity  of  Thimphu  and  Phuentsholing,  with  the 
7. 
busiest section on the short stretch from Thimphu to Semtokha. Traffic on this section averages 
2,280 vehicles per day (vpd), excluding two-wheelers. The next highest traffic level, about 900 
vpd,  is  on  the  Semtokha–Chuzom  section,  which  is  the  common  section  of  the  roads  to 
Phuentsholing and Paro (airport). Traffic then divides roughly equally, at about 450 vpd on the 
roads to Phuentsholing and Paro. On the East-West Highway, traffic reaches 500–600 vpd from 
Semtokha  to  Wangdue,  and  decreases  markedly  further  east,  with  about  100  vpd  to  Trongsa 
and 50–100 vpd further east. A major effort is under way to provide services in smaller towns as 
well as access roads, necessary to give rural areas access to socioeconomic activities. 
 
8. 
All  freight  and  passenger  transport  services  have  been  privatized.  RSTA  regulates  the 
transport  industry  and  sets  tariffs.  The  tariffs  are  binding  for  passenger  traffic  but  considered 
indicative for freight as it is only applicable for hiring by the Government. Freight, operators are 
required  to  obtain  a  business  license  from  the  Ministry  of  Trade  and  Industry.  The  size  of  the 
truck fleet has risen significantly in recent years and increased competition is reported to have 
reduced freight rates. Passenger bus services have been privatized. Commercial bus services 
are provided by 37 bus operators with a total fleet of about 120 vehicles as of December 2004. 
RSTA issues permits to operate bus services, specifying the route, vehicle type, and frequency 
of  services  to  be  operated,  with  priority  given  to  affordability.  The  bus  service  contract  is 
contracted  out  on  a  competitive  basis  by  grouping  profitable  and  nonprofitable  routes  in  one 
package. Routes that cannot be profitable and grouped are contracted out to a single provider 
with a subsidy whereby RSTA pays interest for a loan for the operator to purchase a bus. 
 
9. 
The  Road  Safety  and  Transport  Act  of  1999  defines  the  roles  of  RSTA  and  the  traffic 
police  in  implementing  the  road  traffic  safety  rules.  The  act  reflects  modern  practice  and  the 
traffic  safety  rules  are  in  line  with  international  standards.  Despite  rapid  traffic  growth,  the 
number of reported accidents has only increased from around 250 with 15 fatalities in 1999 to 

 

  

 

 

3

436 with 17 fatalities in 2003. This translates to 6.4 annual fatalities per 10,000 vehicles, which 
is  very  low  in  comparison  with  lower  and  middle  income  countries  where  the  range  is  5–100 
annual  fatalities  per  10,000  vehicles.  However,  the  extent  of  underreporting  of  accidents, 
especially  in  rural  areas,  is  not  known.  Considering  the  high  growth  of  the  vehicle  fleet,  these 
positive statistics may not be sustained. 
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

The Government’s Development Strategy 

 
10. 
The  9th  Five-Year  Plan  (FYP,  2002–2007)  objectives  for  the  road  sector  are  to  (i) 
improve  accessibility  to  socioeconomic  activities  by  building  more  roads;  and  (ii)  enhance  the 
existing  network  with  a  view  to  reducing  travel  time,  road-user  costs,  and  transportation  costs 
for goods and services. The strategies include (i) construction of highways and feeder roads, (ii) 
realignment  of  national  highways,  (iii)  construction  of  double-lane  highways  and  improvement 
along  critical  stretches,  (iv)  maintenance  and  stabilization  of  national  highways,  and  (v) 
replacement  and  reconstruction  of  bridges.  Private  sector  participation,  mechanization  of  road 
construction, and adoption of design and construction with environmental consideration will be 
promoted during implementation of these strategies. The objectives for road transport services 
are to develop safe, reliable, efficient, and affordable passenger and freight transport services. 
The 9th FYP strategies to achieve this objective include (i) focus on safety and environmental 
standards through vehicle inspection, and (ii) expand services through regulation and selective 
support of private transport enterprises. 
 
Under the 9th FYP, DOR road expenditures would amount to Nu6.7 billion, comprising: 
11. 
(i)  new  road  construction,  realignment,  and  widening,  Nu3,575  million  (53%);  (ii)  bridge 
construction and maintenance, Nu634 million (10%); (iii) resurfacing, Nu1,100 million (17%); (iv) 
routine maintenance, Nu819 million (12%); (v) equipment, buildings, and miscellaneous items, 
Nu206 million (3%); and (vi) road administration, Nu300 million (5%). In addition, about 5–10% 
of  the  total  is  required  for  monsoon  repairs  every  year,  which  is  available  from  Government 
contingencies.  Other  road  sector  institutions  have  expenses:  (i)  RSTA  (Nu252  million)  for  bus 
terminals  and  waiting  sheds,  traffic  safety  programs,  and  vehicle  testing  equipment;  (ii) 
Standards and Quality  Control Authority (Nu45 million) for construction of central and regional 
material  testing  laboratories,  procurement  of  laboratory  and  field-testing  equipment,  and 
capacity  building;  and  (iii)  Construction  Development  Board  (Nu18  million)  for  construction  of 
office buildings, purchase of equipment and furniture, and capacity building. 
 
12. 
Accessibility  is  the  key  development  issue  in  the  country.  To  cope  with  socioeconomic 
development and the consequent expansion of vehicular traffic, the existing road infrastructure 
must  be  upgraded  and  improved.  The  country’s  trunk  road  network  is  still  limited  in  terms  of 
coverage  and  is  unable  to  meet  the  growing  demands  of  larger  and  heavier  vehicles.  Limited 
provision of feeder roads adds to the isolation of remote rural areas. While the need to expand 
the  road  network  to  enhance  socioeconomic  activities  in  rural  communities  is  increasing, 
maintenance  of  the  existing  road  infrastructure  is  an  equally  important  and  challenging 
component. The Government needs to allocate its limited budget to all of these requirements for 
development:  expanding  trunk  and  feeder  road  networks  while  maintaining  and  improving  the 
existing  network.  The  ambitious  public  investment  targets  set  forth  in  the  9th  FYP  require 
increased  recourse  to  concessionary  foreign  borrowing,  including  from  ADB,  if  9th  FYP 
objectives and the Government poverty reduction targets are to be met. 
 
 

 

 4 

 

 

 

2. 

External Assistance and Asian Development Bank Strategies 

 
13. 
Development  of  the  road  network  has  depended  upon  external  assistance  with  about 
25%  of  the  road  budget  coming  from  foreign  loans  (5%)  and  grants  (20%).  Appendix  3 
summarizes  recent  external  assistance  in  the  road  sector.  The  Government  portion  includes 
program support from the Government of India of about 15% of the total budget. Besides ADB, 
the main governments and development agencies active in the road sector are the governments 
of Austria, Japan, Netherlands, and Switzerland. The World Bank has the ongoing Rural Access 
Project (RAP). These activities have included considerable institutional support to DOR. Some 
support  is  also  provided  for  the  farm  road  program  through  agricultural  development  projects, 
from  various  sources  such  as  European  Union,  German  Agency  for  Technical  Cooperation, 
International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  (IFAD),  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency  (JICA),  and  Swiss  Agency  for  Development  and  Cooperation.  ADB  continues  to  have 
informal  dialogue  with  the  major  financing  agencies  in  the  sector.  ADB  assistance  has  been 
focusing  on  resurfacing  the  East-West  Highway,  while  JICA  focuses  on  bridges  and 
construction equipment, and World Bank on rural roads. ADB now also takes on the role of rural 
roads and national highways under the Project. For TA in the sector, bilateral funders provide 
capacity  building  on  engineering  aspects,  while  ADB  focuses  on  planning  and  policy  aspects, 
such as road asset management. 
 
ADB involvement in transport and communications so far has been exclusively in roads. 
14. 
Since  1983,  ADB  commitments  have  reached  $28.63  million,  making  roads  the  third  largest 
recipient after social infrastructure and energy. Within the sector, ADB has provided three loans, 
totaling $23.6 million; six advisory TAs, totaling $3.36 million; and five project preparatory TAs, 
totaling  $1.63  million.  Since  1991,  several  of  these  initiatives  have  directly  supported  the 
Government’s various 5-year plans by contributing to the resurfacing of the road network. The 
projects  included  the  East-West  Highway  Maintenance  Project2  and  the  Road  Improvement 
Project (RIP).3 In addition, the Multiproject4 funded the construction of 34 km of roads between 
Samchi and Dorokha, as well as 73 km of forest roads and 10 suspension bridges. 
 
15. 
ADB TA for Road Planning and Management Strengthening (footnote 2) contributed to 
improvements in governance, which provided an improved road policy and management system 
that  facilitated  efficient  budget  allocations  for  road  sector  development  and  maintenance.  The 
TA  also  prepared  a  road  sector  master  plan,  which  became  the  basis  of  the  9th  FYP.  In 
addition, the Road Act, prepared under the TA, was passed by the National Assembly in 2004. 
The act defines a mechanism for road management, including (i) clearly defined responsibilities 
and  rights  of  road  users  and  affected  communities;  (ii)  conditions  and  requirements  for 
construction,  rehabilitation,  maintenance,  and  use  of  roads,  with  focus  on  environment  and 
safety; (iii) road financing and road-user charges; and (iv) functions of agencies responsible for 
monitoring and enforcing the provisions of the legislation. 
 
16. 
ADB  lending  and  nonlending  activities  have  aimed  at  reducing  rural  poverty  through, 
among others, road network expansion. As a result, ADB assistance in the sector has focused

5

on  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  of  the  main  highway  network,  as  well  as  transport  network 
planning  and  management.  The  assistance  to  the  sector  has  provided  and  will  continue  to 
provide  a  number  of  benefits  through  the  following  strategic  sector  objectives:  (i)  continue  to 
enhance the main road network, (ii) ensure adequate maintenance of the existing road network, 
(iii) improve rural accessibility, (iv) support institutional strengthening, (v) promote private sector 
participation,  (vi)  improve  road  technology  and  productivity,  and  (vii)  support  subregional 
linkages. 
 
During  the  next  country  strategy  and  program  period,  reducing  isolation  by  increasing 
17. 
both the reach and quality of the road network to boost connectivity is a main focus for fostering 
pro-poor growth. Roads provide not only access, but also opportunities for opening up areas to 
social services such as health and education. In addition, roads provide an avenue to farmers to 
do  cash-crop  farming  as  markets  and  farms  come  closer  to  each  other.  In  short,  access 
contributes  to  the  attainment  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals,  increased  incomes, 
provision of alternative sources of employment, and poverty reduction. Under the new country 
strategy  and  program  framework,  ADB  will  focus  on  fewer  sectors  but  with  larger  operations. 
This  recognizes  the  Government’s  growing  capacity  to  plan,  design,  and  implement  larger 
projects in Bhutan, and the growing financing requirement to meet poverty reduction objectives. 
It  will  also  contribute  to  a  reduction  in  the  transaction  costs  that  arise,  both  within  ADB  and 
especially to the Government, from processing many small loans. 
 

3. 

Road Maintenance Financing 

 
18. 
The  Government  has  a  strong  record  of  financing  road  maintenance  and  provides 
appropriate amounts for routine and periodic maintenance from the general government budget. 
The  approved  budget  under  the  9th  FYP  for  routine  maintenance  and  resurfacing  is  Nu1,919 
million or Nu383.8 million per annum, which was revised to Nu1,935 million or Nu387.1 million. 
This  includes  a  budget  to  reduce  the  backlog  of  deferred  maintenance.  Excluding  deferred 
maintenance,  the  requirement  for  routine  and  periodic  maintenance  is  estimated  as  Nu270 
million–Nu300 million, depending on the assumption of the unit price or the deterioration level of 
maintainable  roads.  The  physical  completion  of  routine  maintenance  and  resurfacing  as  of  31 
December 2004 is about 50% of the FYP target. The actual expenditure was Nu677.4 million or 
35%  of  the  budget.  This  reflects  that  deferred  maintenance  works  remain,  as  they  cost  more 
than routine and periodic maintenance.  
 
19. 
Routine  maintenance  has  been  totally  funded  by  domestic  revenue,  while  resurfacing 
including deferred maintenance relies on external assistance, e.g., ADB’s RIP, which provides 
about Nu95 million (over 30% of total resurfacing budget) during the first 2 years of the 9th FYP. 
Specific  charges  for  road  use  are  taxes  on  motor  vehicles  levied  by  RSTA,  such  as  annual 
registration/renewal, ownership transfer fee, etc. Other revenues relating to road use include the 
sales tax on fuel, and custom duties and sales tax on vehicles. Revenue relating to road use is 
estimated  at  Nu236  million  in  2003/04,  increasing  from  Nu161  million  in  2000/01,  which  is 
absorbed  in  the  general  government  revenue.  Imposition  of  a  large  fuel  levy  is  currently  not 
feasible  in  the  Bhutanese  context  because  of  implications  for  transport  tariffs  and  the  recent 
increase  in  fuel  price.  Price  parity  should  also  be  maintained  with  Indian  fuel  prices  to  avoid 
distortion in the Bhutanese market, such as cross-border smuggling. Given these difficulties as 
well as low traffic volume, road user charges are being levied at the level required for financing 
both routine and periodic maintenance. The Government assured that routine maintenance and 
resurfacing will be funded totally by domestic revenue after completion of the RIP.

4. 

Private Sector Participation 

For  deferred  maintenance,  which  is  estimated  at  30%  of  the  national  highway,  the 
20. 
Government  assured  that  it  will  secure  the  budget  by  reducing  the  backlog  of  deferred 
maintenance to 20% by the end of the 9th FYP (2007) and eliminating the entire backlog by the 
end of the 10th FYP (2012). By project completion in 2010, the backlog will be reduced to 7%. 
Under  the  9th  FYP,  the  budget  is  already  set  to  achieve  these  targets.  To  secure  the  budget 
required for backlog reduction in the 10th FYP, TA will be provided under the Project for DOR to 
appropriately  propose  the  required  budget  based  on  condition-based  maintenance  planning. 
The  reduction  target  is  considered  realistic.  No  risk  of  a  budget  shortfall  for  maintenance  and 
backlog reduction is anticipated because (i) no substantial reduction in the Government of India 
assistance is envisaged for the medium and long term, and (ii) revenues related to road use will 
continuously be increased. 
 
 
 
21. 
The Government has a policy under the 9th FYP to enhance private sector participation 
in  road  works.  The  amount  of  government-financed  road  works  contracted  out  to  domestic 
contractors was increased from Nu70 million under the 7th FYP (1992–1997) to Nu1,027 million 
under  the  8th  FYP  (1997–2002)  out  of  the  total  Nu2,524  million  (40.7%).  The  private  sector 
participation level is expected to increase substantially under the 9th FYP, e.g., Nu1,000 million 
out of Nu2,233 million (44.8%)5 during the initial 2.5 years of the 9th FYP. The Government is 
committed  to  increasing  the  share  of  participation  of  domestic  contractors  in  works  excluding 
tied grants and loans to more than 50% by the end of the 9th FYP. 
 
22. 
The Government is now planning to corporatize the mechanical division. Equipment and 
machinery will be utilized optimally by leasing these on a commercial basis both to DOR and the 
private  sector.  The  recent  pilot  scheme  of  making  the  division  to  be  self-sustainable  led  to  a 
reduction in the hiring price to the private sector. Corporatization will decrease the difference in 
hiring prices and availability, which will encourage more private sector participation.  
 
23. 
ADB and the World Bank have supported the development of the domestic contracting 
industry through the local competitive bidding (LCB) procedure for the RIP and RAP. The results 
so far are satisfactory. To facilitate development of domestic contractors, all the works under the 
Project  will  be  contracted  to  domestic  contractors  using  the  LCB.  Based  on  the  experience  of 
RIP  and  RAP,  a  maximum  contract  size  of  Nu150  million  is  considered  appropriate  as  the 
threshold for LCB. Under current local contractor registration, of the 38 class A contractors for 
roads and bridges, about half have a sufficient fleet of equipment and would be qualified to carry 
out works of the indicated contract size. 
 

5. 

Capacity Building of Road Sector Institutions 

 
Road  construction  and  maintenance  were  originally  characterized  by  labor  intensive, 
24. 
low-productivity, and high-cost practices, resulting in poor quality roads with poor serviceability 
and  short  service  life.  DOR  retains  a  large  national  work  force  for  routine  maintenance  and 
emergency repair works. It plans to increase productivity from the existing 1 km per person to 
1.5 km per person by the end of the 9th FYP (2007), through scheduled retirements, a freeze on 
new  recruitment,  increasing  mechanization,  and  other  arrangements.  The  construction 
industry’s experience with mechanized road works is increasing as work increases.

Road Safety 

 
27. 
The Road Safety and Transport Regulation of 1999 provides regulations for registration 
and  licensing,  commercial  passenger  vehicles,  traffic  control,  and  enforcement  mechanisms. 
Measures  have  been  undertaken  to  educate  all  drivers  on  basic  safety  precautions  and  many 
driving  refresher  courses  have  been  organized.  Highway  checking  will  be  enhanced  by 
introducing  the  use  of  speed  detectors  and  alcohol  detectors.  Vehicle  inspection  has  been 
conducted, including predeparture inspection for buses and inspection of all vehicles every year, 
except commercial vehicles for which inspection is conducted every half year. One of the major 
measures to reduce accidents is the introduction of roundabouts at various road junctions with 
the  result  that  the  statistics  for  accidents  in  roundabouts  have  fallen  from  81  in  1996  to  41  in 
2003.  Accident  data  has  been  collected  in  a  systematic  manner  with  prescribed  reporting 
formats  since  2002  used  by  16  base  offices  under  four  regional  offices.  Safety  coordinating 
meetings are held involving DOR, City Corporation, police, and dzongkhags. Awareness of the 
need to enhance road safety is increasing. The Government will ensure that road safety audits 
will  be  undertaken  for  the  national  highway  under  the  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Road 
Safety Audit for Road Projects: An Operational Tool Kit (2003) or similar procedure acceptable 
to  ADB,  taking  into  account  Bhutanese  conditions.  A  TA  will  be  provided  under  the  Project  to 
conduct  road  safety  audit  during  design,  construction,  and  maintenance,  which  will  also  help 
DOR strengthen the capacity of road safety audit (para. 61).

Lessons Learned 

its  capacity 

 
28. 
ADB-assisted road projects in Bhutan initially experienced implementation delays. These 
were mainly due to (i) cumbersome government procurement procedures; (ii) unfamiliarity with 
ADB  procedures  and  practices;  (iii)  lack  of  institutional  capacity  in  DOR  for  preconstruction 
processes and construction supervision, including environmental clearance especially for quarry 
sites;  and  (iv)  lack  of  capacity  of  the  domestic  private  sector  in  road  construction  and 
engineering and related services. 
 
29. 
A  series  of  ADB  loans  and  TAs  has  attempted  to  address  institutional  issues.  DOR’s 
capacity  has  been  strengthened  by  provision  of  equipment  and  workshop  facilities,  as  well  as 
training for DOR staff in mechanized road works and equipment maintenance. The construction 
contracting  procurement  process,  including  road  works,  has  been  streamlined  in  the 
Government’s  Financial  Manual.  DOR  has  also  strengthened 
to  satisfy 
interministerial procedures, such as environmental clearance. DOR has enhanced its familiarity 
with  ADB  procurement  procedures.  Through  bilateral  assistance,  especially  from  JICA,  DOR 
continues to strengthen its capacity, especially in technical aspects of road technology such as 
quality assurance and environmental considerations, planning construction, and managing and 
supervising  private  sector  works.  The  private  sector  has  also  been  given  an  opportunity  to 
enhance  its  capacity  through  LCB  in  ADB-  and  World  Bank-financed  projects,  training  and 
capacity-building programs, and substantial amount of works supported by the Government of 
India  through  a  joint  venture  with  India’s  contractors.  For  private  sector  participation  to  be 
sustained, and to enable further consolidation and development of the local industry, a pipeline 
of  road  construction  works  is  required  through  increased  contracting  out  of  improvement  and 
maintenance works. 
 
30. 
Another  cause  of  delays  and  cost  overruns  has  been  inadequate  design,  construction 
planning,  and  supervision.  Comprehensive  detailed  designs  and  construction  plans  based  on 
adequate site investigations are crucial to the timely and satisfactory completion of the Project. 
Without  detailed  site  investigation  and  well-developed  construction  plans,  design  will  require 
many  ad  hoc  adjustments.  Timely  design  is  fundamental,  otherwise,  construction  is  inevitably 
delayed. 
 
31. 
The  capacity  of  DOR  to  carry  out  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  planning  has  been 
strengthened as a result of working with the World Bank project. DOR has already established 
field  offices  to  decentralize  implementation  responsibilities  and,  each  field  office  has  officials 
who  are  conversant  with  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  planning  and  implementation 
procedures.  The  land  acquisition  procedure  of  the  Government  is  transparent  and  well 
established, requiring all stakeholders to participate in land acquisition. DOR is involved in land 
acquisition  from  project  planning  to  completion,  including  the  assessment  and  verification  of 
people  affected and  their  entitlements.  No  delays  in  project  implementation have  been  due  to 
lack of DOR capacity in land acquisition and resettlement. 
 
32. 
The  contracting  regime  is  generally  transparent,  and  open  tendering  is  conducted  in 
accordance with the Financial Manual (1988), which was developed with ADB assistance. DOR 
has  blacklisted  several  suppliers  for  unsatisfactory  performance.  The  Royal  Audit  Authority 
(RAA) undertakes a periodic audit of relevant accounts and statements as part of its mandate 
on  performance  audits  of  government  ministries.  The  Tender  Committee  in  MOWHS  ensures 
that  all  the  bids  received  prior  to  the  deadline  are  opened  and  evaluated  as  stipulated  in  the 
bidding  documents.  The  new  guidelines  for  bid  evaluation  are  to  facilitate  objective  and 
nondiscriminatory  evaluation,  and  determine  the  lowest  evaluated  bid.  Any  changes  to  the 

 

  

 

 

9

tender notices are published in Kuensel, the sole national newspaper. DOR is now aware of a 
certain level of price fixing by contractors when applying prequalification, and has proposed that 
it will adopt postqualification under the Project in line with the ADB single-stage, two-envelope 
procedure. This will enhance the transparency and competition in tendering. The Government’s 
initiative of private sector participation in construction ensures that private sector contractors do 
not face any policy-related constraints for market entry. In respect of anticorruption measures, 
RAA recently started a program of workshops to (i) increase awareness of public officials and 
the  general  public  of  issues  surrounding  corruption,  and  (ii)  promote  discussions  on  current 
policies and guidelines. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

33. 
The objective of the Project is to improve transport efficiency on the trunk road network 
and  expand  accessibility  in  rural  areas,  which  will  contribute  both  to  expansion  of  economic 
opportunities  and  poverty  reduction.  This  objective  will  be  achieved  by  (i)  improving  and 
shortening  a  major  north-south  road,  (ii)  constructing  feeder  roads,  (iii)  enhancing  DOR’s 
capacity  for  road  asset  management,  and  (iv)  facilitating  private  sector  participation  in  the 
domestic  contracting  industry.  The  Project  provides  the  opportunity  for  ADB  to  finance 
improvement  of  a  national  highway  and  construction  of  feeder  roads.  This  reflects  the 
Government  commitment  to  fully  financing  resurfacing  as  well  as  routine  maintenance  using 
domestic revenue when the RIP is completed. 
 
B. 

Outputs 

1. 

National Highway Component 

 
 
The  Project  will  finance  upgrading  of  sections  of  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway 
34. 
(about 140 km of the total 244 km), including a 16 km realignment between the Mangdichu and 
Wangdigang  bridges,  which  will  result  in  a  39  km  reduction  in  highway  length.  Single 
carriageways (3.8 m wide including extra widening at curves) with 1.0 m wide shoulders will be 
built.  The  Project  will  replace  two  temporary  bridges  with  permanent  structures.  The  project 
road, included in the updated 9th FYP, will provide another subregional link with India in addition 
to the existing link via the Thimphu–Phuentsholing road. The rest of the national highway does 
not  need  improvement  due  to  relatively  better  road  conditions  for  less  traffic.  Only  the  current 
maintenance regime will be conducted for this section. The summary of design standards is in 
Appendix 4. The road was designed as a national highway serving domestic traffic movement 
and is not expected to immediately increase cross-border transport movement. Trucks crossing 
the  border  have  no  major  restrictions  or  barriers.  The  link  road  on  Indian  territory  is  in  good 
condition. 
 
 
 
The Project will finance the construction of four feeder roads: Mirchim–Bongo (17.5 km) 
35. 
and  Tekizam–Bjena  (6.5  km)  in  the  west  region,  and  Garbagtang–Autsho  (51  km)  and 
Khardungla–Kangpara (28.0 km) in the east. Single-lane carriageways (3.5 m wide) with 0.5 m 
wide shoulders will be built. The design period is 20 years and the recommended design speed 
is 40 km/hour. The thicknesses of the gravel surface and the granular base course are each 150 
millimeters. The road sections within the vicinity of villages, and for 500 m on both sides, will be 
bituminous surfaced to reduce dust pollution. The feeder roads under the Project are included in 

Feeder Roads Component 

2. 

 

 10 

 

 

 

the  updated  9th  FYP  and  selected  in  accordance  with  the  Government’s  policy  to  realize 
regional  balance  and  rural  access,  and  the  TA  study.  Also,  the  selection  reflects  coordination 
with  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  (farm  roads)  and  funding  agencies,  e.g.,  feeder  roads  by  the 
World  Bank  and  farm  roads  by  IFAD.  While  ADB  continues  to  support  development  agency 
focus  on  the  east  region,  which  has  a  higher  poverty  incidence,  feeder  roads  in  the  west  will 
also be developed to improve rural access. A summary of design standards is in Appendix 4. 
 
C. 

Special Features 

1. 

Environmental Consideration in Design and Construction 

 
36. 
DOR  started  to  introduce  environmental  consideration  for  all  its  new  road  construction 
under the RAP (1999). The methodology adopted for environmental consideration will minimize 
damage  to  the  natural  environment  by  use  of  controlled  blasting,  limited  use  of  bulldozers  (in 
lieu, excavator-tipper combinations are used), use of log and boulder barriers to control slipping 
of  blasted  or  excavated  materials,  and  incorporation  of  bioengineering  techniques  for  slope 
protection. The latest technical specifications for roads and bridges published in February 2005 
adopt  these  methods.  Initial  investment  costs  using  these  methods  with  environmental 
consideration will be 25–30% higher compared with the traditional approach. However, on a life-
-cycle  basis,  this  approach  has  higher  economic  benefits  due  to  the  reduction  in  routine 
maintenance  and  other  recurrent  costs.  The  Project  will  adopt  these  methods  for  all  road 
sections. 
 

2. 

Community Participation in Selecting Routes of Feeder Roads 

 
During  project  preparation,  field  studies  were  conducted  by  using  household  surveys, 
37. 
focus group discussions, village profile surveys, consultations with other stakeholders both on-
site  and  at  headquarters  in  Thimphu,  and  workshops  at  which  findings  were  discussed  and 
roads  and  preliminary  alignment  were  determined.  The  proposed  alignment  was  decided 
through public consultation with communities and consideration of the assessment of hazardous 
and  geotechnical  conditions.  Any  changes  to  the  alignment  will  be  minimal  based  on  more 
detailed engineering studies and consultations with communities. 
 

3. 

Road Safety Measures 

 
38. 
Safety  and  roadside  measures  will  be  incorporated,  such  as  road  safety  structures 
(breast  walls,  retaining  walls,  toe  walls,  and  check  walls),  truck  passing  zones  at  appropriate 
locations, and guard rail/crash barriers at identified black spots or accident-prone areas for the 
national  highway.  The  design  will  incorporate  engineering  measures,  including  required 
widening at curves, vision berms at curves, and proper provision of road markings and signs. In 
addition,  road  safety  audits  will  be  conducted  during  the  detailed  design  for  the  national 
highway.  A  safety  awareness  campaign  will  be  conducted  for  communities  along  selected 
feeder roads.

The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $27.3  million  equivalent  from  ADB’s  Special 
40. 
Funds  resources  to  help  finance  the  Project.  The  loan  will  have  a  32-year  term,  including  a 
grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum  thereafter,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement. 
The Government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s 
Special Funds resources on the basis of these terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that 
these  choices  were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any 
communication or advice from ADB.  
 
41. 
The loan will finance 80% of the total project cost, including the entire foreign exchange 
cost,  and  $6.0  million  or  46.9%  of  the  local  currency  cost.  The  Government  will  finance  the

duties,  land  acquisition,  remuneration  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  and  other

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

The organization chart for project implementation is provided in Appendix 6. DOR will be 
42. 
the Executing Agency. The existing Project Management Office (PMO), which is responsible for 
implementing  the  RIP,  will  be  retained  for  the  Project.  Through  previous  ADB-funded  projects 
and TAs, DOR has obtained relevant experience and established implementation capacity.  
 
43. 
The  PMO  is  headed  by  a  full-time  project  manager  at  the  executive  engineer  level, 
supported by adequate technical and administrative personnel. The PMO will be responsible for 
coordinating, managing, and monitoring the Project. During design and procurement, the office 
will be based in Thimphu. Once phase I civil works have been awarded, the PMO will move to 
Trongsa and two other regional offices will be established in Mirchim and Garbagtang/Mongar. 
 
44. 
The Trongsa office will be responsible for overall project coordination, management, and 
monitoring.  It  will  also  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation  of  the  Gelephu–Trongsa 
sections.  Two  deputy  project  managers  (at  the  assistant  engineer  level),  one  for  the  national 
highway  pavement  strengthening  (four  contracts)  and  the  other  for  the  national  highway 
realignment (two contracts), will be appointed.  
 
45. 
The  Mirchim  office  will  be  headed  by  a  deputy  project  manager,  responsible  for 
implementing  feeder  roads  in  the  west  (three  contracts):  Mirchim–Bongo  and  Tekizam–Bjena. 
Implementation  of  feeder  roads  in  the  east  (six  contracts)  will  be  the  responsibility  of  the 
Garbagtang/Mongar office, led by a deputy project manager.  
 
46. 
Procurement and contract awards for the subsequent phases will be the responsibility of 
the PMO. Each office (PMO and two regional offices) will be responsible for (i) monitoring the 
progress of day-to-day project implementation, and (ii) preparing project progress reports. The 
project  manager  will  consolidate  these  reports  and  submit  them  to  DOR  and  ADB,  and  be 
responsible  for  preparing  withdrawal  applications.  The  project  manager  and  all  deputy  project 
managers will meet on a quarterly basis or as required. 
 

2. 

Implementation Period 

47. 
The Project will be implemented over 5 years inclusive of preconstruction activities, and 
taking  into  account  the  time  required  for  preparing  detailed  design,  bidding  documents,  and 
procurement. Because of the harsh winter and monsoon rains in the summer, the work seasons 
in the project area are limited. Procurement will be carried out in four phases, each covering 3–4 
contract packages. Civil works are expected to commence around April 2007 and be completed 
in June 2010. The tentative implementation schedule is provided in Appendix 7. The schedule 
assumes that survey and design carried out by DOR will be started mid-2005, and the loan will 
be effective by the end of October 2005. 
 

3. 

Procurement 

48. 
All procurement financed by the ADB loans will be carried out in accordance with ADB 
Guidelines for Procurement and the Government’s tender procedures acceptable to ADB. The 
civil works contracts will be mainly for low-value works spread over a wide geographic area, and 
are unlikely to be attractive to foreign contractors. Domestic procurement procedures have been 
satisfactory to ADB under the RIP. Therefore, civil works contracts will be procured using LCB 

 

  

 

 

13

procedures.  This  is  also  in  line  with  the  Governments’  initiative  of  facilitating  private  sector 
development in the construction industry. The indicative contract packages are in Appendix 8. 
 
49. 
For  civil  works,  bidders  will  be  postqualified  by  applying  a  single-stage,  two-envelope 
bidding  procedure.  Considering  that  the  civil  works  are  standard,  and  the  works  have  been 
packaged to enable bidders to prepare their proposals quickly, the bid submission period is 30 
days. Eligible bidders will be either domestic private sector companies appropriately registered 
with  the  Construction  Development  Board  or  foreign  companies  operating  in  Bhutan.  The 
ongoing and previous ADB-assisted and other externally financed projects have demonstrated 
that domestic contractors are capable of successfully performing road improvement contracts. 
 
50. 
supports the Government’s initiative to take advance procurement action.

the-job  training  to  counterpart  staff  and  domestic  consultants.  The  consultant  will  be  recruited

5. 

Disbursement Arrangements 

55. 
Loan disbursements will be in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook as 
amended from time to time and detailed arrangements between the Government and ADB. For 
consulting  services,  loan  funds  will  be  disbursed  using  ADB  procedures.  For  civil  works,  an 
imprest account with DOR will be established at the Bank of Bhutan, with an initial amount not 
to exceed estimated expenditures for the next 6 months or 10% of the loan amount, whichever 
is lower. DOR will be responsible for monitoring this account, including monthly reconciliation of 
the accounts and preparation of the withdrawal applications for liquidation/replenishment of the 
account.  To  expedite  disbursement  during  implementation,  statement  of  expenditures  will  be 
used  to  reimburse,  liquidate,  or  replenish  the  imprest  account  for  any  individual  payments  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $100,000.  
 

6. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

56.   DOR and the PMO will maintain separate records and accounts adequate to identify the 
financing  resources  received  and  expenditures  made  on  the  Project.  These  project  accounts 
and  related  financial  statements  will  be  audited  annually  in  accordance  with  sound  auditing 
standards by auditors acceptable to ADB. The audited reports and financial statements will be 
submitted to ADB not later than 9 months after the end of each fiscal year. A TA will be provided 
during  the  new  country  strategy  and  program  period  for  strengthening  RAA  capacity  to 
undertake  audits  in  a  timely  and  quality  manner.  In  addition  to  financial  audits,  RAA  will  also 
start undertaking performance audits. Once RAA is improved after the TA, a shorter submission 
deadline will be examined. The imprest account and statement of expenditures will be audited 
as  part  of  the  regular  annual  audit.  The  auditor’s  opinion  of  the  examination  of  the  imprest 
account  and  statement  of  expenditures  should  be  separate  in  the  auditor’s  report.  DOR  was 
made  aware  of  ADB  policy  on  delayed  submission,  and  also  of  the  importance  of  satisfactory 
and acceptable quality of audited reports. 
 

7. 

Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 

57. 
DOR will monitor the preparation and implementation of the Project in accordance with 
the implementation schedule. In addition, DOR with assistance from the consultant will monitor 
project  performance  indicators,  including  traffic  volume,  transport  benefits  (vehicle  operating 
costs and travel time), number of road accidents, and amount of contracting out to the domestic 
contracting  industry.  Baseline  indicators  will  be  collected  and/or  updated  before  construction 
start.  DOR  will  set  up  a  project  performance  management  system  within  3  months  from  loan 
effectiveness  and,  assisted  by  the  project  supervision  consultant,  monitor  these  indicators 
annually during project implementation, and 3 months after project completion. 
 

8. 

Project Review 

58. 
A  project  inception  mission  will  be  fielded  soon  after  loan  effectiveness,  and  regular 
reviews  will  follow  annually.  In  2008,  the  Project  will  require  a  detailed  midterm  review  by  the 
Government and ADB to consider the Project’s progress and agree upon any changes in scope 
or implementation to achieve the project objectives.  
 
59. 
DOR will monitor project preparation and implementation in accordance with the project 
processing and implementation schedule and time-bound milestones, and keep ADB informed 
of any significant deviations resulting in the milestones not being met. Assisted by consultants, 
DOR  will  submit  quarterly  progress  to  ADB;  the  report  format  will  be  developed  during  the 

 

  

 

 

15

inception mission. Within 3 months of physical completion, DOR will submit a project completion 
report in a format acceptable to ADB. 
 
60. 
For  purposes  of  monitoring  project  implementation  progress,  DOR  will  prepare  and 
submit to ADB brief monthly progress reports in such form and detail as required. The report is 
an  executive  summary  of  the  detailed  reports,  including  basic  data,  utilization  of  funds, 
achievement  of  immediate  development  objectives,  implementation  progress,  compliance  with 
covenants, and major issues and problems (format and content will be attached to the project 
administration memorandum to be developed during appraisal).  
 

IV. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

A  TA  for  $300,000  for  Capacity  Building  in  Road  Safety  Audit  and  Road  Asset 
61. 
Management  (Appendix  9)  will  be  provided  to  (i)  equip  DOR  and  RSTA  with  the  capacity  for 
road  safety  audits,  and  (ii)  enhance  DOR’s  capacity  in  road  asset  management.  The  TA  will 
provide  training  in  road  safety  audit  to  DOR  and  RSTA  officials,  using  the  project  national 
highway as a pilot case, and develop a road safety audit manual and tool kit, in line with ADB’s 
Road  Safety  Audit  for  Road  Projects:  An  Operational  Tool  Kit  (2003)  or  similar  procedure 
acceptable to ADB, taking into account Bhutanese conditions. The project national highway will 
be designed with a road safety assessment in 2007 taking into account the outcome of the TA; 
DOR  and  RSTA  are  expected  to  be  able  to  conduct  and  review  road  safety  audits  of  new 
construction or improvement projects after 2007. The TA  will also assist DOR in  developing  a 
road  maintenance  program  on  a  road  condition  basis.  The  previous  ADB-financed  TA  for  the 
Road Planning and Management Strengthening Project in 2002 introduced the concept of road 
asset  management  in  DOR,  which  will  be  the  basis  of  this  capacity  building.  With the  TA,  the 
Government could prepare the 10th FYP by 2006 taking into account the commitment to finance 
periodic  and  routine  maintenance  by  domestic  revenue  assured  under  the  Project.  DOR  is 
expected to be able to conduct periodic surveys of road conditions and traffic volume by 2008, 
and  prepare  the  budget  estimate  for  the  11th  FYP  (2012–2017)  before  project  completion  in 
2010. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, and be carried out 
by individual international consultants, to be recruited in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants. International inputs of about 9 person-months for road safety expertise and  
2 person-months for road asset management are required. 
 

V. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Technical Aspects 

A. 
 
62. 
The improvement to the Gelephu–Trongsa national highway will provide the second road 
link with India and facilitate subregional trade. Various safety measures suitable to Bhutanese 
conditions are incorporated in the design. Overall, the Project will improve transport efficiency, 
speed up traffic, improve travel conditions, and reduce journey time and vehicle operating costs 
(VOCs). The Project also incorporates environmental considerations in design and construction, 
e.g., bioengineering in slope protection, controlled blasting. 
 
B. 
 
63. 
The  Project  will  facilitate  DOR’s  institutional  strengthening  and  contribute  to  overall 
transport  efficiency  and  safety,  thus  improving  the  returns  and  sustainability  of  investments  in 
roads and encouraging a wide range of other economic activities that make use of them. These 
will  provide  efficient  and  safe  transport,  and  contribute  to  economic  growth  and  poverty 

Policy and Institutional Aspects 

 

 16 

 

 

 

Social Aspects 

reduction. The Project will provide a batch of road works, which will increase the proportion of 
civil  works  and  engineering  assigned  to  the  domestic  private  sector  by  using  LCB.  The 
increased  exposure  of  the  private  sector  to  the  works  will  contribute  to  private  sector 
development. Overall, the Project will improve the efficiency of road sector institutions, including 
DOR and the private sector contracting industry. 
 
C. 
 
The  social  survey  indicates  that  with  improved/new  roads  and  better  connectivity, 
64. 
farmers  will  grow  larger  marketable  surpluses.  On  the  feeder  roads,  farmers  presently  carry 
their surpluses to the nearby markets on the backs of animals or by self carry loading. A larger 
marketable  surplus  will  also  provide  for  more  agricultural  wage  employment,  particularly 
benefiting the poor. The Project will enable reliable access to social services, particularly health 
care  services,  education  facilities,  and  supply  of  drinking  water.  The  Project  will  have  limited 
negative  social  impact.  ADB’s  regional  TA  for  Assessing  the  Impact  of  Transport  and  Energy 
Infrastructure  on  Poverty  Reduction8  demonstrates  that  roads  impact  income  and  nonincome 
dimensions of poverty reduction, especially roads passing through poorly served rural areas. 
 
65. 
The  Project  will  have  no  negative  gender  impacts.  In  the  areas  of  the  feeder  roads, 
women will specifically benefit in two areas where they presently dominate with regard to work 
activities:  (i)  easier  access  to  external  markets,  and  (ii)  increased  local  retailing  opportunities. 
Women  also  regularly  travel  to  health  care  centers.  Women  may  also  benefit  more  than  men 
from increased access to schools as enrolment rates for girls have been lower than for boys. 
 
The  Project  will  address  any  potential  risks  of  human  immunodeficiency  virus/acquired 
66. 
immunodeficiency  syndrome  (HIV/AIDS)  and  women/children  trafficking  threats  that  can  be 
aggravated with the increased connectivity in the project areas. The Government has a 15-year 
National  STD  (sexually  transmitted  disease)/AIDS  Control  Program.  This  is  a  multisectoral 
initiative involving all sections of society in Bhutan since 1988, assisted by bilateral development 
agencies,  United  Nations  agencies,  and  the  recent  World  Bank  grant. Through  basic  health 
units  in  project  areas, the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH) runs  clinics  that  include  HIV/AIDS 
awareness programs. A clause on health awareness and occupational health will be included in 
the Project's  contract  documents,  and  DOR  and  MOH have  agreed  to  coordinate  provision  of 
the awareness program along the project corridor. In addition, a social specialist engaged by the 
Project  will  monitor  the  situation  and  report any  issues  to  MOH, which  has  agreed  to  provide 
assistance  and  guidance as  required.  In  the  meantime,  a project  for  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty 
Reduction  funding  is  being  prepared;  it  includes  a  health  awareness  program  specifically  for 
road maintenance workers, in coordination with MOH. 
 
67. 
No  separate  disadvantaged  groups  are  likely  to  be  adversely  affected  by  the  Project. 
The  Project  will  have  a  monitoring  and  evaluation  system  to  supervise  adverse  impacts  on 
potentially  vulnerable  groups  and  initiate  measures  to  mitigate  such  adverse  impacts  through 
resettlement plans. 
 
68. 
summary of the poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10.

Land Acquisition and Resettlement Aspects 

D. 
 
69. 
On the project national highway, no land acquisition and resettlement impacts will result. 
All the land for the 16 km realignment is Government-owned forestland; no private land will be 
needed.  The  entire  project  impact  area  for  the  realignment  stretch  is  Government-owned 
forestland and rocky mountains. Even if the construction were to take place outside of the right-
of-way, it will not require any acquisition of private land. The other sections for national highway 
improvement are only to strengthen the existing roads with minor modification for other design 
features  such  as  widening/cutting  curves.  The  area  for  this  modification  is  minimal  and 
construction will be conducted within the existing right-of-way with no requirement for any land 
acquisition of private property. For the construction of the four feeder roads, small amounts of 
land may be acquired but no resettlement impacts are envisaged. Most of the land required is 
Government  owned,  with  less  than 10%  of  required  land  estimated  as  private  property.  Given 
the  sparse  nature  of  settlements,  the  acquisition  of  private  land  can  be  minimized.  Since  all 
affected persons will only be identified after the detailed design, a resettlement framework has 
been formulated and endorsed for land acquisition and resettlement by the Government in line 
with  ADB policy  on  involuntary  resettlement.9  The  Government  disclosed  the  resettlement 
framework to those affected through the local newspaper (Kuensel) on 16 April 2005 in English 
and local language. The information is also made available to those affected by respective local 
authorities (Gups). 
 
70. 
Any  civil  works  contract  will  not  be  awarded  unless  ADB  approves  the  submitted 
resettlement plans. The Government is providing assurance that no construction activity will be 
undertaken  on  any  piece  of  land  before  compensation  and  assistance  have  been  rendered  to 
those  people  in  accordance  with  policy  requirements.  The  design  consultants  will  assist  with 
preparing and monitoring the resettlement plans (Supplementary Appendix A). 
 
E. 
 
71. 
The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  found  that  an  environmental  impact 
assessment  (EIA)  was  required  for  the  national  highway  component.  The  existing  Gelephu–
Trongsa stretch passes through approximately 59 km of the Jigme Singye Wangchuck National 
Park and approximately 10 km of the Royal Manas National Park. In addition, the proposed 16 
km Wangdigang–Mangdechu realignment passes through the buffer zone of the Jigme Singye 
Wangchuck  National  Park.  Based  on  these  findings,  the  proposed  improvement  of  Gelephu–
Trongsa  was  classified  as  “A”  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines (2003). Subsequently, an EIA was prepared for the national highway component.10 
The  feeder  road  component  does  not  require  an  EIA  because  none  of  the  feeder  road 
components,  consisting  of  four  feeder  roads  connecting  Mirchim–Bongo,  Autsho–Garbagtang, 
Khardungla–Kangpara,  Tekizam–Bjena  with  a  total  length  of  103  km,  pass  through  national 
parks  and  no  major  environmental  issues  were  identified.  Consequently,  the  IEE  study  of  the 
feeder road component is sufficient as the final environmental assessment. The summary EIA 
comprises the EIA for the national highway and the IEE for the feeder roads, and was circulated 
to the Board on 25 May 2005.

Almost all predicted significant adverse impacts of the Project occur during construction. 
72. 
The characteristics of the impacts are significant, short term, and reversible. These impacts are 
manageable  as  almost  all  can  be  minimized  through  the  proposed  mitigation  measures 
incorporated  in  the  engineering  design  known  as  environment-friendly  road  construction.  This 
design will be adopted in constructing the feeder roads as well as in strengthening the national 
highway  and  constructing  the  16  km  realignment  and  feeder  roads.  Most  of  the  costs  for 
environment-friendly  road  construction  are  incorporated  in  the  construction  costs.  To  minimize 
the  environmental  impacts  on  the  national  parks,  the  highway  will  not  be  widened  where  it 
passes  through  the  parks.  Furthermore,  the  locations  for  hot-mix  and  crusher  plants,  and 
construction  camps,  as  well  as  for  disposing  of  spoil  materials,  will  be  selected  in  close 
consultation with the park managers. 
 
The  permanent  and  irreversible  impacts  of  the  Project  will  mostly  occur  along  the 
73. 
realignment: (i) loss of 66,038 m2 of vegetative cover; (ii) loss of about 4,500 trees with diameter 
at breast height (dbh)>10 centimeters, and deriving from these; (iii) loss of wildlife habitat; and 
(iv) a marginal reduction in aesthetic beauty. From these four impacts, only the loss of trees can 
be  quantified  in  monetary  terms.  Based  on  current  commercial  rates  for  logs  in  the  Forestry 
Development Corporation  auction yards, the estimated total commercial value of the timber that 
will  be  felled  is  approximately  Nu52.0  million.  Felled  trees  are  required  to  be  handed  over  to 
local forestry officials who then pass them to the Forestry Development Corporation for auction. 
This value will thus not be a loss to the economy. In addition, these losses will be compensated 
by planting trees and grass in the sharp slope areas. 
 
74. 
An environmental management plan (EMP) was prepared and will serve as a guideline 
for  incorporating  environmental  measures  to  be  carried  out  by  DOR,  project  manager, 
contractors,  and  other  parties  concerned  for  mitigating  possible  impacts  associated  with  the 
Project. The EMP must be updated at the beginning of project implementation, especially after 
the  detailed  engineering  design  is  completed,  when  detailed  locations  and  frequency  of 
monitoring can be defined more concisely. 
 
75. 
The realignment and feeder roads have yet to be completed and continued monitoring is 
needed  to  examine  whether  remedial  actions  are  required  to  deal  with  unexpected  impacts,  if 
any.  In  addition,  the  EIA  and  IEE  including  EMP  for  these  project  components  need  to  be 
updated during the final engineering design. If the engineering design will lead to changes of the 
existing project plan, the revised EIA and IEE including EMP need to be submitted to relevant 
Government agencies for approval as well as to ADB for concurrence. 
 
F. 
 
76. 
The  economic  assessment  (Appendix  11)  was  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB 
Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The highway design and maintenance model 
(HDM4) was used to calculate VOCs and time costs with modification for conditions in Bhutan. 
For the Gelephu–Trongsa national highway, the principal benefits are savings in VOC and time 
savings.  For  the  realignment  section  (the  16  km  bypass—Wangdigang–Tingtibi),  three 
additional minor benefits have been added: (i) reduced accident costs due to a shorter route, (ii) 
reduced road closures due to an alternative route being made available, and (iii) benefits from 
additional feeder road functions as it will serve as a feeder road for settlements around the area 
presently not served by roads. The same benefits as feeder roads were estimated. Benefits for 
the four feeder roads are based on the World Bank RAP model, which was recalibrated with the 
updated information contained in the later DOR model. Both these models are underpinned by 
the  roads  economic  decision  model  developed  by  the  World  Bank  for  the  evaluation  of  low-

Economic Aspects 

 

  

 

 

19

Project Risks 

volume roads. Overall, the two main assumptions are that (i) production potential in rural areas 
without  road  access  is  presently  untapped,  and  (ii)  in  postconstruction  the  economies  of  rural 
areas  within  a  day’s  walk  to  a  new  feeder  road  will  become  similar  to  those  rural  areas  that 
already  have  road  access.  The  benefits  are  (i)  production  surplus  due  to  increased  transport 
activities,  (ii)  VOC  savings  incurred  due  to  better  road  conditions  using  designs  with 
environmental consideration, (iii) transport savings (less pack animals/human porters), (iv) trail 
maintenance  saving,  (v)  reduced  road  closures  from  landslides  (only  for  Garbagtang–Autsho 
roads), (vi) access to health services, and (vii) access to education. The production surplus is by 
far the largest benefit. The last two benefits are assumed to be incurred by those living in the 
project influence areas because of increased mobility resulting from the Project. 
 
77. 
A  benefit  and  cost  analysis  was  completed  for  the  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway 
and the four feeder roads. The estimated economic internal rates of return (EIRR) are 17.4% for 
the national highway, 13.4 % for Mirchim–Bongo (17.5 km), 17.6% for Tekizam–Bjena (6.5 km), 
12.6% for Garbagtang–Autsho (51.0 km), and 12.8% for Khardungla–Kangpara (28.0 km). The 
sensitivity tests show the robustness of the analysis. The case of no time savings resulted in an 
EIRR of less than 12% for three feeder roads. However, the probability that time savings will not 
be  realized  is  marginal.  Furthermore,  the  analysis  is  based  on  a  conservative  estimation:  the 
traffic volume and growth rate estimated were about half of those used by the World Bank RAP 
study, considering uncertainty of generated traffic after opening the roads to traffic.  
 
G. 
 
78. 
The  Project  has  been  carefully  formulated  to  manage  and  mitigate  risks,  especially 
based on suggestions provided in the country assistance program evaluation for Bhutan11 and 
project performance audit report of the East-West Highway Maintenance Project.12 The risk of 
ad  hoc  design  changes,  which  could  result  in  the  realignment  section  of  the  national  highway 
and feeder roads will be avoided by preparing detailed design on a 10–15 km rolling plan basis 
immediately  followed  by  construction.  In  addition,  an  appropriate  duration,  e.g.,  4  months,  for 
construction  planning  including  quarry  sites  clearance  will  be  given  to  contractors  before 
commencing work, which allows contractors to better plan the construction schedule. Technical 
advice will be provided by in-house JICA experts for DOR’s survey and design works as part of 
their  overall  DOR  capacity-building  program.  The  risk  of  delayed  implementation  has  been 
mitigated by adopting advance action and postqualification, and setting up project management 
units on-site for close construction supervision. The competition of domestic contractors and the 
sufficient  capacity  of  survey  and  design  will  be  ensured  by  phasing  a  group  of  contract 
packages  for  bidding.  The  supervision  consultant  will  ensure  timely  and  quality  project 
implementation. 
 
79. 
The  risk  of  increasing  road  accidents  will  be  mitigated  through  a  systematic  review  of 
road designs through the road safety audit. The risk of underbudgeting for road maintenance is 
mitigated  through  a  TA  for  preparing  the  asset  management  plan  under  the  10th  FYP  (2007–
2012).  Sufficient  budget  has  already  been  budgeted  under  the  9th  FYP  (2002–2007).  As  the 
country program evaluation and project performance audit report suggest, the TA is designed to 
reflect  local  conditions,  develop  simpler  practical  systems,  and  make  consultants  input  more 
DOR-oriented,  by  providing  DOR  staff  with  specific  tasks  to  be  completed  with  minimal  inputs 
given by international consultants for overall guidance.
