Appendix 2 

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

 
A.  
 
Transport, communications, trade, and commerce contributed 16% to the overall gross 
1. 
domestic product at the end of the 8th Five-Year Plan (FYP), 1997–2001. Road transport is the 
only internal transport mode in Bhutan, besides a few ropeways. The country has no domestic 
flights,  no  railways,  and  no  navigable  rivers.  However,  many  areas  are  not  road  served  an 
extensive  network  of  mule  tracks  exists  throughout  the  country.  Half  the  country’s  population 
lives  more  than  half  a  day’s  walk  from  the  nearest  motorable  road.  Other  than  the  traditional 
surface border crossings with India, only one airport provides limited air access to the rest of the 
world.  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  involvement  in  transport  and  communications  so  far  has 
been only in the road sector. 
 
2. 
The 9th FYP objectives for roads and bridges are (i) improving accessibility to social and 
economic activities by building more roads, and (ii) enhancing the existing network with a view 
to  reducing travel  time,  road  user  costs,  and  transportation  costs  for  goods  and  services.  The 
strategies to be followed include (i) promotion of private sector participation; (ii) mechanization 
of  road  construction,  design,  and  construction  with  environmental  consideration;  (iii) 
construction  of  highways  and  feeder  roads;  (iv)  realignment  of  national  highways;  (v) 
construction  of  double-lane  highways  and  improvement  of  critical  stretches;  (vi)  maintenance 
and stabilization of national highways; and (vii) replacement and reconstruction of bridges. The 
objectives  for  road  transport  services  are  the  development  of  safe,  reliable,  efficient,  and 
affordable passenger and freight transport services. The strategies to achieve this objective in 
the  9th  FYP  include  (i)  a  focus  on  safety  and  environmental  standards,  and  (ii)  expansion  of 
services through regulation and selective support of private transport enterprises. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
In  a  landlocked  country  like  Bhutan,  the  socioeconomic  development  of  the  country 
depends largely on an efficient and reliable road network. Since the construction of the 179 km 
Phuentsholing–Thimphu Highway in 1959, the country has expanded the national road network. 
It has now about 4,153 km of motorable roads, including 1,577 km of national highways, 459 km 
of district roads, 1,205 km of feeder roads, 117 km of urban roads, 251 km of farm roads and 
543  km  of  forest  roads.  This  gives  a  road  density  of  0.1  km/square  kilometer  (km2)  and  5 
km/1,000 inhabitants. The latter is relatively high in comparison with countries with similar size 
and  income  level,  and  is  explained  by  the  scattered  settlement  of  population.  Despite  the 
present road network, many rural communities still remain unconnected. 
 
4. 
All  national  highways  and  nearly  half  of  the  district  roads  and  feeder  roads  are  paved; 
however, 20% of national highways, 53% of district roads, and 86% of feeder roads are in poor 
condition.  Roads  with  narrow  carriageway  widths  were  built  along  steep  hillsides  prone  to 
landslides.  Roads  become  difficult  to  use  during  the  winter  months  and  rainy  season. 
Improvement and maintenance of the existing road network are in urgent need. Because of the 
mountainous terrain, the area of land suitable for agriculture is limited and the population of less 
than  700,000  people  is  distributed  in  remote  scattered  settlements.  This  situation  makes  the 
construction and maintenance of roads extremely difficult and costly. In addition, the wide use of 
manual resurfacing only provides a low quality pavement.  
 
5. 
The vehicle fleet has grown rapidly in recent years. From a total of 13,600 vehicles at the 
end of 1997, it reached over 26,700 at the end of 2004, a growth rate of over 15% per annum. 

Road Network and Traffic 

  

Appendix 2 

25 

Light  vehicles,  and  in  particular  taxis,  increased  faster  than  the  average,  while  two-wheelers 
increased at a slower pace. Almost 90% of vehicles are in the western areas of Thimphu and 
Phuentsholing.  Over  two  thirds  of  the  light  vehicles  are  in  the  capital  area,  while  70%  of  the 
trucks  are  registered  at  Phuentsholing.  To  streamline  the  transport  system,  all  motor  vehicle 
related activities, including registration and licensing, roadworthiness, and emission tests were 
consolidated under the Road Safety and Transport Authority (RSTA) at the beginning of 1997. 
 
6. 
Traffic  volumes  are  highest  in  the  vicinity  of  Thimphu  and  Phuentsholing,  with  the 
busiest section on the short stretch from Thimphu to Semtokha. Traffic on this section averaged 
2,280 vehicles per day (vpd), excluding two-wheelers. The next highest traffic level, about 900 
vpd,  is  on  the  Semtokha-Chuzom  section,  which  is  the  common  section  of  the  roads  to 
Phuentsholing and Paro (airport). Traffic then divides roughly equally, at about 450 vpd on the 
roads to Phuentsholing and Paro. On the East–West Highway, traffic reaches 500–600 vpd from 
Semtokha to Wangdue, and falls markedly further east, with about 100 vpd to Trongsa and 50–
100 vpd further east. A major effort is under way to provide services in smaller towns, as well as 
access roads, necessary to give rural areas access to social and economic activities. 
 
7. 
The  Road  Safety  and  Transport  Act  of  1999  defines  the  roles  of  RSTA  and  the  traffic 
police  in  implementing  the  road  traffic  safety  rules.  The  act  reflects  modern  practice  and  the 
traffic  safety  rules  are  in  line  with  international  standards.  Despite  rapid  traffic  growth,  the 
number of reported accidents has only increased from around 250 with 15 fatalities in 1999 to 
436 with 17 fatalities in 2003. This translates to 6.4 annual fatalities per 10,000 vehicles, which 
is  very  low  in  comparison  with  lower  and  middle  income  countries  where  the  range  is  5–100 
annual  fatalities  per  10,000  vehicles.  However,  the  extent  of  underreporting  of  accidents, 
especially  in  rural  areas,  is  not  known.  Considering  the  high  rate  of  vehicle  increase,  these 
positive statistics may not be sustained. 
 
C. 
 
8. 
Until  the  early  1990s,  most  of  the  country's  main  road  network  was  constructed  and 
maintained  by  DANTAK  (an  organization  under  the  Army  Engineering  Corp  of  Indian  Border 
Force) and financed by the Government of India as a grant. About 15% of Bhutan’s main road 
network  (574  km,  of  which  498  km  are  national  highways,  62  km  district  roads,  and  16  km 
feeder roads) is still maintained by DANTAK and funded by the Government of India, in addition 
to selected new construction and upgrading works. The Department of Roads (DOR) under the 
Ministry  of  Works  and  Human  Settlement  (MOWHS)  has  direct  responsibility  for  2,120  km, 
including 1,062 km of national highways, 415 km of district roads, 554 km of feeder roads, and 
89 km of urban roads. 
 
9. 
The  Government  has  been  in  the  process  of  redefining  its  role  from  that  of  executing 
project implementation to service purchaser of transport infrastructure and services. MOWHS is 
responsible  for  the  overall  policy  making  and  planning  of  road  development  and  maintenance 
through the Policy and Planning Division based on the requirement proposed by DOR. DOR is 
still  heavily  involved  in  survey  and  design  works  through  the  Survey  and  Design  Division,  but 
the  number  of  DOR  staff  has  been  considerably  reduced.  An  increased  amount  of  road 
construction  and  maintenance  work  has  been  contracted  to  private  contractors,  in  line  with 
improvements to their financial and technical capacity. DOR will also set up an investigation and 
development  division  to  enhance  its  capacity  for  road  asset  management  and  technology. 
Under  MOWHS,  the  Standard  and  Quality  Control  Authority  is  responsible  for  standards  and 
quality assurance of all construction works. The Construction Development Board is responsible 
for  registration  of  contractors  and  consultants,  facilitating  private  sector  development  and 

Road Sector Management 

 26 

Appendix 2 

Road Transport Industry 

participation. Road safety is under the responsibility of RSTA under the Ministry of Information 
and  Communications,  except  engineering/design  aspects,  which  is  coordinated  with  DOR. 
RSTA is also responsible for regulation of the transport industry. 
 
Road  construction  and  maintenance  was  characterized  by  labor  intensive,  low 
10. 
productivity, and high-cost practices, resulting in poor quality roads with poor serviceability and 
short service life. However, the construction industry’s experience with mechanized road works 
was improved due to the increase in the amount of works. The number of class A contractors, 
which require a large fleet of equipment and machinery as registration criteria, has increased to 
38.  DOR  retains  a  large  labor  force,  National  Work  Force,  for  routine  maintenance  and 
emergency repair works. DOR, however, plans to increase the productivity of the National Work 
Force, from the existing 1 km per person to 1.5 km per person by the end of the 9th FYP (2007), 
through  natural  decrease  with  no  new  recruitment,  increase  of  mechanization,  and  other 
arrangements. 
 
D. 
 
11. 
All  freight  and  passenger  transport  services  have  been  privatized.  RSTA  regulates  the 
transport  industry  and  sets  tariffs.  The  tariffs  are  binding  for  passenger  traffic  but  considered 
indicative  for  freight  as  is  they  are  only  applicable  for  hiring  by  the  Government.  For  freight, 
operators are required to obtain a business license from the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The 
size  of  the  truck  fleet  has  risen  significantly  in  recent  years  and  increased  competition  is 
reported  to  have  reduced  freight  rates.  For  passengers,  bus  services  have  been  privatized. 
Thirty-seven bus operators provide commercial services with a total fleet of about 120 vehicles 
as  of  December  2004.  RSTA  issues  permits  to  operate  bus  services,  specifying  the  route, 
vehicle type, and frequency of services to be operated, with priority given to affordability. 
 
12. 
Freight  transport  is  generally  provided  by  medium-sized  2-axle  trucks,  the  poor  road 
geometry precluding the use of larger vehicles. Freight rates are not regulated, but are subject 
to various factors including the availability of backhauls and the season. A typical charge may 
be around Nu2.5–Nu3.0 per ton per km. No vehicle weight and dimension legislation is in place, 
other than a regulation that the maximum load carried is 10 tons in the plains and 8 tons in the 
hills.  Special  permits  to  exceed  these  loads  are  given  to  vehicles  involved  with  development 
projects.  A  weighbridge  is  operated  by  the  Revenue  and  Customs  Department  near 
Phuentsholing. Normal practice involves transshipment of goods at Phuentsholing to and from 
Indian trucks of around 12-ton capacity, which can operate easily in the flat terrain south of the 
border.  Indian  registered  trucks  can  enter  Bhutan,  but  require  a  permit  for  each  journey  and 
cannot carry backhaul cargo from Bhutan to India. 
 
13. 
For bus services, most of the existing permits were issued in 1997 and are valid for 10 
years.  The  bus  service  is  contracted  out  on  a  competitive  basis  by  grouping  profitable  and 
nonprofitable  routes  as  one  package  to  provide  some  measure  of  cross-subsidization.  Routes 
that  cannot  be  profitable  and  grouped  are  contracted  out  to  a  single  provider  with  a  subsidy 
whereby  RSTA  pays  interest  for  a  loan  for  the  operator  to  purchase  a  bus.  The  fares  are 
published in the Fare Chart for Passenger Transport Services. Current fares have been updated 
since  2001.  The  increase  was  about  4%  to  the  2001  schedule,  which  is  generally  Nu0.5  per 
passenger km for ordinary (38-seat) buses. 
 
The taxi fleet has expanded greatly in recent years. As of December 2004, 1,235 taxis 
14. 
were registered in Thimphu, 504 in Phuentsholing, 26 in Gelephu, and 20 in Samdrup Jongkhar. 
Almost all are operated by owner-drivers. No limit has been established for the number of taxis

Road Expenditures and Revenues 

licensed. Meters were progressively introduced with fares set at Nu9 per km with the initial ride 
of  Nu12  per  km  during  daytime  (Nu20  during  nighttime)  including  the  initial  1  km.  Fares  are 
negotiated  on  some  long  distance  journeys  per  passenger  at  the  similar  level  of  express 
minibus services. 
 
E. 
 
15. 
During  the  9th  FYP,  road  expenditures  (by  DOR)  would  amount  to  Nu6.7  billion, 
comprising  (i)  new  road  construction,  realignment,  and  widening,  Nu3,575  million  (53%);  (ii) 
bridge  construction  and  maintenance,  Nu634  million  (10%);  (iii)  resurfacing,  Nu1,100  million 
(17%);  (iv)  routine  maintenance,  Nu819  million  (12%);  (v)  equipment,  buildings,  etc.,  Nu206 
million (3%); and (vi) road administration, Nu300 million (5%). In addition, about 5–10% of the 
above total is required for monsoon repairs every year, which is available from the government 
contingencies. 
 
16. 
In  addition,  expenses  for  other  road  sector  institutions  include  (i)  RSTA  (total  Nu252 
million)  for  bus  terminals  and  waiting  sheds,  traffic  safety  programs,  and  vehicle  testing 
equipment; (ii) Standard and Quality Control Authority (Nu45 million) for construction of central 
and  regional  material 
field-testing 
equipment, and capacity building; and (iii) the Construction Development Board (Nu18 million) 
for construction of office buildings, purchase of equipment and furniture, and capacity building in 
support  of  three  main  activities:  classification  and  registration  of  contractors  and  consultants, 
collection  and  dissemination  of  construction  industry  information,  and  administration  of  a 
construction-related arbitration system. 
 
17. 
Specific  charges  for  road  use  are  taxes  on  motor  vehicles  levied  by  RSTA  such  as 
annual  registration/renewal,  ownership  transfer  fee,  etc.,  which  amounted  to  Nu88  million  in 
2003/04.  Other  revenues  relating  to  road  use  include  the  sales  tax  on  fuel  (Nu31  million  in 
2000/01)  and  custom  duties  and  sales  tax  on  vehicles  (Nu70  million  in  2000/01).  Revenue 
related  to  road  use  is  estimated  at  Nu236  million  in  2003/04  from  Nu161  million  in  2000/01. 
Imposition  of  a  large  fuel  levy  is  currently  not  feasible  in  the  Bhutanese  context  because  of 
implications for transport tariffs and the recent increase in fuel price. Price parity should also be 
maintained  with  Indian  fuel  prices  to  avoid  distortion  in  the  Bhutanese  market,  such  as  cross-
border smuggling. Given these difficulties as well as low traffic volume, road user charges are 
being levied at the level required for financing both routine and periodic maintenance. MOWHS 
proposes an increase in vehicle taxes to broaden the Government’s revenue base.  
 
F. 
 
18. 
The  Government  has  a  strong  record  of  financing  road  maintenance  and  provides 
appropriate  amounts  required  for  routine  and  periodic  maintenance.  The  annual  average 
expenditure  as  of  December  2004  under  the  9th  FYP  is  Nu271  million,  which  covers  the 
estimated  requirement  of  routine  maintenance  for  the  total  road  network  and  periodic 
maintenance  for  200  km  per  year.  The  routine  maintenance  is  totally  funded  by  domestic 
revenue, while resurfacing relies on external assistance, e.g., ADB’s Road Improvement Project 
(RIP),  which  amounts  to  about  Nu95  million  (over  30%  of  total  resurfacing  budget)  during  the 
first  2  years  of  the  9th  FYP.  In  line  with  the  self-reliance  policy,  the  Government  intends  to 
finance  both  routine  maintenance  and  resurfacing  totally  by  domestic  revenue  after  the 
completion  of  the  ongoing  RIP.  The  Government  also  puts  the  highest  priority  on  budgeting 
routine  and  periodic  maintenance  every  year.  In  addition,  the  Government  will  secure  the 
budget for reducing the backlog of deferred maintenance. 

Maintenance

Appendix 2 

Private Sector Participation 

G. 
 
19. 
The Government has a policy under the 9th FYP to enhance private sector participation 
in  road  works.  The  amount  of  government-financed  road  works  that  was  contracted  out  to 
domestic  contractors  has  increased  from  Nu70  million  under  the  7th  FYP  (1992–1997)  to 
Nu1,027  million  under  the  8th  FYP  (1997–2002)  out  of  the  total  Nu2,524  million  (40.7%).  The 
private  sector  participation  level  is  expected  to  increase  substantially under  the  9th  FYP,  e.g., 
Nu1,000 million out of Nu2,233 million (44.8%)1 during the initial 2.5 years of the 9th FYP. The 
Government intends to increase the share of participation of domestic contractors. 
 
20. 
ADB and the World Bank have supported the development of the domestic contracting 
industry through the local competitive bidding procedure for the RIP and the World Bank-funded 
Rural  Access  Project.  The  results  so  far  are  satisfactory.  Based  on  the  experience  of  the  two 
projects, a contract size at the maximum amount of Nu150 million is considered appropriate as 
the threshold for local competitive bidding. Under current local contractor registration, 38 class A 
contractors are available for roads and bridges; about half have a sufficient fleet of equipment 
and would be qualified for the works of that amount.

Appendix 4 

PROJECT ROAD AND SUMMARY OF DESIGN STANDARDS 
 

National Highway 

A. 
 
The Project will upgrade the Gelephu–Trongsa national highway (about 245 kilometers 
1. 
[km]), and will include a 16 km realignment between the Mangdichu (km 98.3) and Wangdigang 
bridges  (km  153.6),  which  will  result  in  an  approximately  39.3  km  reduction  in  length.  The 
Project  will  include  the  replacement  of  two  temporary  bridges  with  permanent  structures:  at 
Wangdigang at km 155.2 and Yeshigang at km 224.7. 
 
2. 
The existing road is an almost continuous chain of back-to back curves, resulting in low 
travel  speeds  and  substantial  safety  problems.  The  average  carriageway  width  is  3.8  meters 
(m), but this varies between 3.0 m and 4.0 m—including extra widening on curves. The average 
width of shoulders on the valley side is 2.5 m, varying between 1.0 m and 3.0 m, while on the 
hillside the average width is 0.8 m, varying between 0 m and 2.0 m. The carriageway, including 
shoulders  of  major  highways,  is  presently  surfaced  with  a  premix  carpet.  The  drains  on  the 
hillsides  are  about  0.6  m  wide,  generally  V-shaped,  shallow,  and  mostly  unlined.  Lack  of 
adequate  drainage  at  some  places  is  causing  seepage,  slope  instability,  and  roadbed 
settlement.  During  the  monsoon,  landslides  are  frequent.  Landslides  and  settlement  problems 
have been recorded in about 30 places.  
 
3. 
The design criteria adopted are in accordance with the Road Design Manual of Bhutan 
and other standards, including American, British, and Indian, as appropriate. Geometric design 
standards are varied to suit the traffic levels and terrain conditions. As the projected traffic after 
20 years will remain below 1,000 vehicles per day (vpd), the road is classed as a “low traffic.”   
Except for the first 10.5 km Gelephu–Geleg Zam section, with traffic of about 5,000 vpd passing 
through flat or rolling terrain, the road is entirely confined to mountainous terrain with horizontal 
curvatures of 600 degrees/km and rises and falls 45 m/km).  
 
4. 
Except  for  the  16  km  long  realignment,  the  Project  will  be  implemented  within  the 
existing right-of-way (ROW). On the realigned section, it was also possible to avoid the need for 
resettlement.    Minimizing  cost  and  the  need  for  minimum  land  clearance,  cuts  and  fills,  were, 
however, important other criteria when selecting this new route.  The requirement for rock cuts 
on side slopes has also been minimized, that plant cover could be maintained and in areas of 
unstable  soils,  side  slopes  will  be  benched.    All  other  construction  within  environmentally 
sensitive  areas,  will  be  confined  to the  existing  ROW—though  there  may  be  a  need  for  minor 
widening/cut on curves. 
 
5. 
 

A detailed description of the design approach is as follows: 

Cross  section.  Single  carriageway,  width  3.8  m  (including  extra  widening  at 
curves). Earth shoulders 2x1.0 m. As per Bhutanese standards, the road should 
be a two-lane, single carriageway (6.0 m wide) but such option was not found to 
be  economically  justified—the  applied  reduced standards  do,  however,  conform 
to present practice in Bhutan. 

Right-of-way.  A  30  m  wide  ROW  has  been  recommended  for  the  realignment 
section.  Pavement  strengthening  sections  will  be  constructed  within  existing 
ROW.

Design speed. As per the Bhutanese standards, 60 km/hour will be the design 
speed. This is, however, only economically justifiable in flat/rolling terrain. If this 
standard were to be adopted in mountainous terrain, the entire road would have 
to  be  realigned—and  this  is  clearly  not  an  economically  justifiable  solution.

(v) 

Pavement. Both the new and rehabilitated pavements are designed for 20 years 
and  take  into  account  projected  traffic  loading,  existing  pavement  structure, 
subgrade  California  bearing  ratio,  and  quality  of  materials  available.  For 
rehabilitation  double  bituminous  surface  treatment/asphalt  concrete  (DBST/AC) 
surfacing,  wet  mix  macadam  (WMM)  base  course  and  profile  correction  is 
recommended.  For  the  realignment,  the  following  pavement  composition  is 
recommended: 
(a)  DBST surfacing, 
(b)  250 millimeters (mm) WMM, and 
(c)  150 mm granular subbase  (GSB). 

(vi) 

Realignment. Only one realignment is recommended—between the Mangdichu 
and Wangdigang bridges—it is 16 km long and saves a distance of 39.3 km. The 
realignment,  however,  bypasses  Zhemgang  town,  the  biggest  settlement 
between Gelephu and Trongsa and a district headquarter. 

(vii)  Bridges. The highway has 21 bridges. Of these, 18 are in sound condition and 
only periodic maintenance is recommended. One of three temporary bridges, the 
Panjuramni bridge, is in the process of being replaced with a permanent structure 
(40 ton loading). The remaining two bridges, Wangdigang and Yeshiganag, each 
40 m long are, therefore, included in the Project. 

(viii)  Drainage.  Over  about  70%  of  the  road  length,  the  existing  drains  need  to  be 
lined.  Of  the  approximately  1,300  culverts,  9  need  reconstruction  (2  m  opening 
and 6 m wide) and 169 need 2.0 meter extensions.

7. 
The Project includes the construction of four feeder roads: (i) Mirchim–Bongo (17.5 km), 
(ii)  Garbagtang–Autsho  (51.0  km),  (iii)  Khardungla–Kangpara  (28.0  km),  and  (iv)  Tekizam–

8.  
These feeder roads will mostly follow the existing tracks, which connect villages and are 
now  used  by  pedestrians  and  animals.  The  presently  determined  alignments  are  based  on 
1:50,000  maps  with  40  m  contours,  supplemented  by  on-site  reconnaissance  surveys.  The 
alignments  will  need  to  be  finalized  during  detailed  design/project  implementation,  when  more 
detailed  information  on  the  local  terrain,  soil,  and  geologic  conditions  and  the  locations  of 
agricultural land and buildings are known.

carriageway  and  shoulder  width  plus  1.5  m  on  either  side  for  safety  and  drainage 
considerations. The design speed is 40 km/hour. 
 
10. 
Based on traffic loading, subgrade strength, and materials availability, a gravel-surfaced 
pavement is recommended. The design period for the  initial gravel pavement is 10 years  with 
the option of upgrading, if the traffic justifies this. The thicknesses of the gravel surface and the 
granular base course are each 150 mm. The road sections within the vicinity of villages, and for 
500 m on both sides, will be bituminous surfaced to reduce dust pollution. 
 
The drainage system recommended includes culverts, bridges, side drains, cut-off/ catch

ease of construction.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CONSULTANTS 

Background 

 
A. 
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Road  Network  Project  provides  opportunities  for 
1. 
road  sector  institutions,  especially  the  Department  of  Roads  (DOR)  and  Road  Safety  and 
Transport Authority (RSTA) to use the Project as a pilot case to conduct a road safety audit. 
 
The  Technical  Assistance  for  Road  Safety  Audit  and  Road  Asset  Management  will 
2. 
provide  assistance  to  DOR  to  strengthen  its  capacity  for  asset  management,  providing  DOR’s 
Road  Maintenance  Management  (RMM)  Unit  staff  with  opportunities  for  learning  how  road 
maintenance  planning  is  prepared  in  other  countries.  It  will  equip  DOR  with  regular  and 
systematic  traffic  counts,  and  road  inventory  and  condition  surveys  to  provide  a  sound  and 
objective basis for planning and monitoring road development and maintenance programs. This 
is very timely as the Government needs to have an appropriate budgeting proposal from DOR 
for preparing the 10th Five-Year Plan to achieve the commitment assured under the proposed 
loan.  
 
3. 
The TA has two components: (i) road safety audit, and (ii) road asset management. The 
TA  not  only  assists  these  government  agencies  to  conduct  road  safety  audits  and  road  asset 
planning under the Project, but also embeds the system to continuously conduct these activities 
in a systematic and sustainable manner after the Project.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 

A. 

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

 
Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty analysis?  
 

 

 

  Yes 

    No 

 

Is the sector identified as a 
national priority in country poverty 
partnership agreement?   

 
 Yes 
 
  No 

 

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
 
The country strategy and program update for Bhutan (2005–2006) identified transport development as a 
key requirement for poverty reduction. The Government has given the development of road infrastructure 
the highest priority in the 9th Five-Year Plan. The Government recognizes the importance of an efficient, 
reliable road network in a landlocked country where about 30% of the geogs (blocks) are not connected to 
feeder  roads,  and  another  30%  are  only  partially  connected.  The  inadequate  road  system  keeps  many 
farmers dependent on subsistence agriculture with no, or limited, access to markets, education, and health 
care.  The  Bhutanese  have  articulated  the  development  of  farm  and  feeder roads as  the  highest  priority, 
through their block development committees and district development committees.  

B.  Poverty Analysis                                         Poverty Classification :  General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
During  the  last  5  years,  data  on  poverty  has  increased.  Of  central  importance  are  the  findings  of  the 
Household  Income  and  Expenditure  Survey  2000:  A  Report  on  Income  and  Expenditure,  Poverty 
Measurement  and  Socioeconomic  Profile  of  Households—Planning  Commission,  October  2001.  Other 
primary data derives from field surveys, and other Government of Bhutan statistical documentation. 
 
In  2004,  estimated  gross domestic product (GDP) per  person  was  about Nu44,880 ($1,020).  Bhutanese 
incomes  are  low  and  especially  in  the  project  areas  of  (i)  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway,  about 
Nu10,630—some 32.5% are believed to be living below the Nu8,976 per year poverty line; and (ii) areas of 
the feeder roads, average individual incomes are only Nu4,660—80% are believed to be living below the 
poverty  line.  Large  parts  of  the  economies  in  these  areas  are  subsistence  and  nonmonetized.  The 
Government,  having  recognized  the  multiple  dimensions  of  poverty  has  targeted  a  range  of  health, 
education, and other programs at the populations of these areas and sees road access as fundamental to 
their involvement in the wider economy and as a tool to improve access to education and health facilities. 
 
The indicators of human development show that life expectancy in Bhutan is rising rapidly—from 48 years 
in 1984 to 66 years in 1998.  Infant mortality, remains however high—60.5 per 1,000 live births in 2000.  
Adult  literacy  is,  however,  only  (i)  59%  in  the  project  areas  of  the  Gelephu  to  Trongsa  national  highway 
and (ii) 68% in the areas of the feeder roads.  In the country as a whole, the rate was 54% in 1998 but is 
now believed to be much higher.1 
 
The socioeconomic survey carried out for the social analysis revealed that 79.5% of the households along 
the  Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway  and  82%  of  those  in  the  broad  influence  area  of  the  proposed 
feeder  roads  engage  in  agriculture  and  allied  activities  to  maintain  their  livelihood.  The  agriculture 
practiced  is  subsistence-based;  nevertheless,  38%  of  the  produce,  mostly  cash  crops,  grown  along  the 
national highway and 22% of that grown in the broad influence areas of the feeder roads, is a marketable 
surplus.  The survey  indicates  that with improved/new  roads and better connectivity,  farmers would  grow 
larger  marketable  surpluses.  On  the  feeder  roads,  farmers  presently  carry  their  surpluses  to  the  nearby 
markets on animal backs or by self carry loading. A larger marketable surplus will also provide for more 
agricultural  waged  employment—particularly  benefiting  the  poor.  The  Project  will  also  enable  reliable 
access  to  social  services—particularly  health  care  services,  education  facilities,  and  supply  of  drinking 
water.  The  issue  of  drinking  water  is  important;  however  its  provision  is  hampered  by  inaccessibility 
because the materials necessary for the installation of drinking water facilities cannot be brought in easily.  
                                                 
1   In the 20 years prior to 1998, literacy rates quadrupled.

43 

 
Estimated poverty impact ratios include the following: 
•  For feeder roads: the proportion of persons living below the poverty threshold is estimated to be 80%.  
Overall,  the  net  present  value  to  the  poor  is  substantial,  Nu311  million,  and  exceeds  the  overall  net 
present value, Nu82 million. The overall poverty impact ratio is more than 100%. 

•  For the Gelephu–Trongsa Road: the proportion of people living below the poverty threshold is 

estimated to be 32.5%. The poverty impact ratio is 78% and most benefits will go to the poor.  

 
C.  Participation Process 

 

  No 
  No 

  Yes 
  Yes 

Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
During  project  preparation,  in  addition  to  the  20%  baseline  socioeconomic  surveys,  approximately  40 
focus group discussions/community consultations were carried out in the influence areas. These surveys 
ascertained  the  needs  of  stakeholders  and  the  risks  likely  to  arise  from  the  Project.  All  those  consulted 
were united in welcoming the benefits that improved access and/or road conditions would provide.   
 
The rural communities in Bhutan are organized into geog (block) development groups for discussion and 
self-help. All households are required to be at these meetings called by the gup (head of the block). In this 
context,  the  planning  process  is  essentially  participatory  with  priorities  and  needs  identified  by 
communities  and  passed  through  the  gewog  yargay  tshogchun  (block  development  committees)  to  the 
dzongkhag  yargay  tshogchung  (district  development  committees)  and  then  to  the  dzongkhag  (district) 
administration  and  national  Government.  Government  policy  decisions  about  the  nature,  format,  and 
implementation of policy are channelled down to the geogs (block) and villages via the same chain.  
 
The community participation aspect of the Project should center around these organizations and focus on 
the  target  population’s  needs and demand.  On  the  feeder  roads, the  most  important  benefits  will be  the 
ability  to  ensure  timely  delivery  of  marketable  surpluses,  and  the  stimulation  of  new  market-
oriented/employment activities.   
 
D.  Gender Development 
The  study  revealed  no  significant  discrimination  against  women  in  Bhutan.  The  socioeconomic  survey 
showed  no  fixed  gender-specific  roles,  although  some  activities  may  be  predominantly  undertaken  by 
women  or  men;  women  and  men  traditionally  have  equal  status  for  most  socioeconomic  activities.  The 
studies also revealed that rural women are becoming more visible in both household and other activities, 
and women are frequently taking on additional work to ensure a comfortable lifestyle for their families.   
 
Along  with  men  in  the  areas  of  the  feeder  roads,  women  will  benefit  by  (i)  easier  access  to  external 
markets,  (ii)  increased  local  retailing  opportunities,  and  (iii)  easier  access  to  health  care  centers  and 
education  facilities.  Women  may  also  benefit  more  than  men  from  the  increased  access  to  schools.  
Traditionally enrolment rates in schools have been lower for girls than for boys. Potential risks of HIV/AIDs 
and  women/children  trafficking  threats may  be  aggravated by  the  increased  connectivity of  the  project 
areas, however, the Project will address these issues through its mitigating measures.

The Project will benefit all the population groups and 
consequently not differentially or adversely affect any

The Project will address any potential risks of human 
immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency 
syndrome (HIV/AIDS) and women/children trafficking 
threats that can be aggravated with the increased 
connectivity in the project areas. The Government has a 
15-year long National STD (sexually transmitted 
disease)/AIDS Control Program. This is a multisectoral 
initiative involving all sections of society in Bhutan since 
1988, assisted by bilateral funding agencies, United 
Nations agencies, and the recent World Bank 
grant. Through basic health units in project areas, the 
Ministry of Health (MOH) runs clinics that include 
HIV/AIDS awareness programs. A clause of health 
awareness and occupational health will be included in 
the Project's contract documents, and DOR and 
MOH have agreed to coordinate the provision of the 
awareness program along the project corridor. In 
addition, a social specialist engaged by the Project will 
monitor the situation and report any issues to 
MOH, which has agreed to provide assistance and 
guidance as required. In the meantime, a project for 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction funding is being 
prepared, which includes a health awareness program 
specifically for road maintenance workers, in coordination 
with MOH.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC ASSESSMENT 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
The  road  components  of  the  Project  comprise  improvement  to  five  sections  of  the 
1. 
Gelephu–Trongsa  national  highway;  and  construction  of  four  feeder  roads—two  in  the  west 
region and two in the east. The existing Gelephu–Trongsa national highway is characterized by 
roughness and in some places by unnecessarily long routes. The feeder roads will provide road 
access to unconnected rural areas. 
 
B. 
 
For the Gelephu–Trongsa national highway, traffic counts and origin/destination surveys 
2. 
were  carried  out  in  May/June  2004  at  numerous  locations  along  the  244.5km  length.  After 
adjustments for seasonal and daily variations, vehicles-per-day (vpd) figures are shown in Table 
A11.1 starting with the southern end of the highway.

3. 
In  the  economic  assessment,  the  vpd  figures  were  converted  to  average  annual  daily 
traffic (AADT) and these AADT figures are the base traffic volumes for normal traffic as of 2004. 
Generated traffic on the highway was considered to be 20–25% of normal traffic. 
 
4. 
During  the  last  10  years,  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  averaged  about  6.7% 
per  annum.  In  2002,  GDP  growth  was  7.7%.  According  to  the  Asian  Development  Outlook 
2005,1 GDP growth is estimated to have grown 7.0% in 2004 and is expected to average about 
8.0%  annually  over  FY2005–FY2007.  Between  1997  and  2003,  the  average  annual  growth  in 
the  vehicle  fleet  was  12.9%  for  light  vehicles  and  9.3%  for  heavy  vehicles.  Over  the  9-years 
from  1995  to  2003,  fuel  sales  grew  by  an  average  of  11.5%  per  annum.  Based  on  these,  the 
traffic growth rates were applied for normal traffic (Table A11.2).

Appendix 11 

Traffic Forecasts for the Feeder Roads 

C. 
 
5. 
During the processing of the ongoing Rural Access Project (RAP) in Bhutan, the World 
Bank used a feeder road economic model that reflects three main developmental points: firstly 
that the construction of feeder roads in close proximity to national highways can be expected to 
bring wider benefits than just traditional transport savings; secondly that production potential in 
rural  areas  without  road  access  is  presently  untapped;  and  thirdly  that,  postconstruction,  the 
economies  of  newly  connected  rural  areas  will  become  similar  to  rural  communities  already 
enjoying  road  access.  The  four  feeder  roads  to  be  constructed  under  the  Project  will  all  be 
linked to respective national highways. 
 
6. 
As  a  consequence  of  the  RAP,  and  in  line  with  the  9th  Five-Year  Plan  initiatives  to 
expand  rural  access,  DOR  commissioned  a  study  that  researched  and  developed  the  World 
Bank  model  in  more  detail,  including  traffic  and  socioeconomic  analysis  in  rural  areas  already 
having road access. The final report for the DOR model became available in 2005. For the four 
feeder roads under the Project, the economic assessment is based on the World Bank model in 
combination with the more recent traffic and socioeconomic research contained in the DOR final 
report. 
 
7. 
The World Bank and DOR models hinge on defining rural accessibility. In Bhutan’s rural 
areas,  a  walk  of  2–3  days  to  the  nearest  road  is  usual.  Reducing  this  to  even  1  day  walking 
distance  to/from  a  road  is  considered  to  be  very  beneficial.  Villagers  already  enjoying  access 
have stated that a distance of 1 day walking allows them to go to the road to send produce by 
truck or for other transport services (often staying overnight with relatives), or for services such 
as  health  centers  and  community  schools  located  near  the  road.  A  common  practice  is  for 
school children to stay with relatives, if the road/school area is within a day’s walking distance, 
so  that  parents  can  visit  them  often  with  food  and  other  supplies.  A  longer  distance  is 
considered  too  far  for  such  purposes.  It  was  concluded  that  villages  within  a  day’s  walking 
distance  (about  15  km)  fall  within  the  direct  beneficiary  zone  of  project  feeder  roads.  In  the 
economic assessment for the four feeder roads under the Project, this conclusion was adopted.  
 
8. 
Based on the work carried out under the World Bank and DOR models, AADT volumes 
(motorized) have been estimated as of 2004 for a typical newly opened feeder road. The AADTs 
(traffic  generation)  are  expressed  in  terms  of  “per  200  population”  living  within  a  day’s  walk 
(Table A11.3).

9. 
These  AADTs  are  used  in  the  economic  assessment  for  the  four  project  feeder  roads, 
and are lower than those used in the RAP and DOR model. The RAP used a total of 22 vehicles 
(AADT), while the DOR model used a total of 20 vehicles (AADT). The lower AADT figures used 
for  the  project  analysis  reflect  a  more  conservative  approach,  bearing  in  mind  that  not  much 
motorized  traffic  exists  in  the  project  influence  areas  of  the  four  feeder  roads,  thus  making 
forecasting even more uncertain.  
 
In the World Bank and DOR models, the assumed traffic growth was slightly over 20% 
10. 
per annum for the first 5 years following construction completion. This growth rate is deemed to 
be  overly  optimistic  when  compared  with  Bhutan’s  GDP  growth  and  the  range  of  norms  for 

  

Appendix 11 

47 
 

Benefits 

Economic Costs 

transport elasticity. Accordingly, in the economic assessment for the four feeder roads the traffic 
growth rates are the same as those used in the economic assessment for the Gelephu–Trongsa 
national highway. 
 
D. 
 
11. 
The economic costs comprise construction, routine maintenance, periodic maintenance, 
and land acquisition. Economic costs are derived from the financial costs and are expressed in 
constant  2005  prices.  Price  contingencies  and  taxes  and  duties  are  excluded.  Physical 
contingencies  are  included.  A  conversion  factor  of  0.9  is  used  to  convert  the  financial  cost  of 
nontradeable goods to economic costs. 
 
E. 
 
12. 
For the five sections of the Gelephu–Trongsa national highway, benefits were calculated 
using the highway design and maintenance model (HDM4). The principal benefits are savings in 
vehicle operating costs (VOC) and time savings. Benefits for generated traffic were treated as 
being  50%  of  those  for  normal  traffic.  For  one  of  the  five  sections  (the  16km  bypass—
Wangdigang–Tingtibi), three additional minor benefits have been added: reduced accident costs 
due to a shorter route, reduced road closures due to an alternative route being made available, 
and  benefits  from  additional  feeder  road  functions  due  to  realignment  of  the  Mangdichu–
Wangdigang bridges.   
 
13. 
Benefits  for  the  four  feeder  roads  are  based  on  the  World  Bank  RAP  model  and  the 
updated information contained in the later DOR model. Both of these models are underpinned 
by the roads economic decision model developed by the World Bank for the evaluation of low-
volume  roads.  Overall,  the  two  main  assumptions  are  that  production  potential  in  rural  areas 
without road access is presently untapped, and that in postconstruction the economies of rural 
areas within a day’s walk to a new feeder road will become similar to those rural areas already 
enjoying road access.  
 
14. 
The  benefit  calculations  for  the  four  feeder  roads  involved  several  steps:  forecasts  of 
traffic  volumes,  VOC  and  travel  time  (all  traffic  will  be  generated  traffic),  and  of  the  value  of 
transport benefits and additional traffic benefits from feeder road construction; then, estimates of 
the elasticity of expenditure on transport to expenditures in other sectors of the rural economy. 
These  other  sectors  are  expected  to  realize  benefits  as  follows:  increased  agriculture 
production, increased mining and quarrying activities, increased activity in the electricity and gas 
sectors,  increased  activity  in  the  construction  sector,  increased  trade  activities,  and  increased 
financial  sector  activities.  Other  (minor)  benefits  comprise  discontinuation/reduction  of  present 
transport  methods  (pack  animals  and  human  porters)  and  reductions  in  present  trail 
maintenance. 
 
15. 
Based on the World Bank RAP model, two further benefit streams were added: improved 
access to health care facilities and improved access to education. These benefits are assumed 
to  be  incurred  by  those  living  in  the  project  influence  areas  due  to  increased  mobility  by  the 
Project. Underlying the health benefits are three main factors: forecasts of population growth in 
the 15 to 59 age bracket, an assumption of 4 days reduced sickness/absence from work, and an 
assumed reduction of 25% in the expected death rate.  
 
16. 
The  education  benefits  are  derived  from  estimates  of  added  recurrent  costs  due  to 
increased enrolment in various categories of school, added capital costs of additional enrolment 

 

  48 

Appendix 11 

Economic Internal Rate of Return  

A detailed list of assumptions is in the attachment to Supplementary Appendix G. 

in various levels, training costs associated with increased enrolment, additional earnings while 
at  school  (vacation  jobs  and  help  at  home),  net  additional  earnings  due  to  improved 
education/training, and savings due to the local upgrading of schools to junior high school. 
 
In  summary,  the  benefit  streams  for  the  four  feeder  roads  (over  40  years)  comprise: 
17. 
production  across  numerous  sectors,  VOC  reductions  due  to  better  road  conditions  using 
designs with environmental consideration, transport savings (less pack animals/human porters), 
less trail maintenance, access to health facilities, and access to improved education. Over the 
first 30 years, production is by far the largest benefit.  
 
18. 
 
F. 
 
19. 
The economic evaluation discounted the stream of benefits and costs over the analytical 
period:  for  the  national  highway  component,  the  construction  period  plus  20-year  benefit 
streams;  and  40  years  for  the  feeder  roads  in  line  with  the  World  Bank  model,  taking  into 
account the long-term benefit of access to education. 
 
20. 
For  the  national  highway  component,  design  standards  of  4–9  options  have  been 
considered  and  most  cost-effective  design  standards  were  identified  for  each  section.  For  the 
feeder road component, six feeder roads, each of which has 2–5 routes have been considered 
and  the  most  cost-effective  route  for  the  four  roads  were  selected  in  consideration  of 
geotechnical conditions and in consultation with communities. 
 
21. 
The  combined  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  five  sections  of  the 
Gelephu–Trongsa national highway is 17.4%. The EIRR for the four feeder roads is 13.4% for 
Mirchim–Bongo,  12.6%  for  Garbagtang–Autsho,  12.8%  for  Khardungla–Kangpara,  and  17.6% 
for Tekizam–Bjena. 
 
G. 
 
Sensitivity tests were applied: construction costs plus 10%, benefits minus 10%, and no 
22. 
time  savings.  Table  A11.4  summarizes  the  results  showing  that  the  quantified  economic 
benefits are considered robust to various sensitivity tests. For the Garbagtang-Autsho road, the 
EIRR falls below 12% but it is marginal. For three feeder roads, the EIRR falls below 12% in the 
case  of  no  time  savings.  The  probability  of  time  savings  not  being  realized  is  marginal. 
Furthermore, the analysis does not include additional benefits like the effect of price change due 
to extra VOC savings considered in the World Bank study, and all of these figures are based on 
the  conservative  estimation  of  traffic  volume  and  growth  rate,  compared  with  the  World  Bank 
study, taking into account uncertainty of generated traffic after the road is opened to traffic.
